documents.content:
It was, as you know, through the good graces of our Ambassador, the estimable Comte de Froulay, that Saint-Palaye and I found ourselves granted a rare privilege. He had arranged for us to witness a session of the Great Council, a spectacle of Venetian governance, for the election of the General of the Galleys – an office of no small consequence, I was assured.

The journey to the Doge’s Palace on that August morning was itself a prelude to the pomp we were to observe. Our gondola, sleek and black as a shark, cut smoothly through the canals, conveying us past the grand façades that rose directly from the water, their ancient stones reflecting the bright summer light. We disembarked at the Piazzetta, a place I have described to you before as a perpetual theatre, always teeming with a colourful array of figures – merchants, masked nobles, foreign dignitaries, and the ever-present vendors of orvietan. The air, already thick with the heat of the day, hummed with a thousand conversations, a constant, low murmur that seemed to be the very breath of Venice.

Ascending the Giants' Staircase, its white and violet marble cool beneath our feet, we passed through several antechambers, each adorned with paintings and sculptures that spoke of centuries of power and artistic patronage. These spaces, though grand, felt somewhat ill-maintained, a common observation in these ancient palaces. Finally, we were ushered into the Sala del Maggior Consiglio itself.

My initial impression was of overwhelming scale. It was an immense hall, far larger than any assembly room I had ever seen, its ceiling a riot of gold leaf and vibrant frescoes, notably Veronese’s *Triumph of Venice*, which seemed to float above us like a vision. At the far end, dominating the space, stood Tintoretto’s colossal *Paradiso*, its dark, aged tones providing a severe backdrop to the raised dais where the Doge’s throne, now empty, was flanked by the seats of the councillors and the Inquisitors of State. A lower dais ran along the perimeter, lined with long rows of benches arranged in aisles, already filling with patricians.

The heat, despite the lagoon-facing windows, was becoming oppressive, and the sheer number of bodies exacerbated it, creating a stifling atmosphere. Yet, the nobles, clad in their mandated black togas – some heavier, lined with fur, though today they must have been made of lighter silk – seemed accustomed to it. Their powdered wigs, often towering and voluminous, struck a curious contrast with the ancient cut of their robes, a blend of Rococo fashion and medieval tradition.

They entered without any discernible order, a swirling tide of black and red. The high-ranking officials, those in their distinct scarlet robes, sought their designated places, while others, a great many of them, dispersed across the hall. It was clear their aim was to prevent undue noise in such a vast assembly, but to my ears, it was an utter failure. The hall buzzed with a constant, almost deafening chatter, a "sabbat de l'autre monde," as I noted at the time. Small groups formed, heads leaned in conspiratorially, and whispers mingled with louder pronouncements. It was less a solemn deliberative body and more a bustling marketplace of influence, where men "played about" while awaiting the main event. I saw many of the *Barnabotti*, the impoverished nobles, clustering together, their votes their only remaining currency, no doubt already pledged for a meal or a promise of protection. It was a scene both majestic and utterly human, full of the very intrigues I had heard so much about during my stay.

After what felt like an eternity of this animated anticipation, the first stirrings of the formal proceedings began. Near the Grand Chancellor's station on the dais, a large wooden urn was brought forth. It was one of those ingenious *bussole*, designed for secrecy, with a hidden tube for the balls. The Chancellor, a figure of stern authority in his black toga and wide, fur-lined stole, surveyed the assembly.

A boy, no older than eight or ten, dressed in a simple white tunic, was then led forward. This was the *Ballottino*, whose youthful innocence was meant to guarantee the fairness of chance. He held the urn, a heavy thing of polished wood, as the nobles began to approach, one by one. There was a palpable tension in the air as each man reached in, his hand disappearing into the urn's opening. The fate of their participation, for this initial stage, rested on the small, silent ball he would draw.

I watched, fascinated, as the procession unfolded. Some nobles, upon drawing a silver ball, would give a barely perceptible shrug, a resigned sigh, and return to their seats, their brief moment of hope extinguished. Others, clutching a gold ball, would straighten their shoulders, a flicker of triumph in their eyes, though quickly masked by a veneer of patrician composure. These were the fortunate ones, destined to be electors for the General of the Galleys. They joined a substantial number of others who, by virtue of their existing high offices, were electors by right, their positions already marked by the deeper red of their robes. It was a peculiar blend of pure chance and established power, a system that only Venice, with its ancient traditions, could have devised. The sorting of the gold and silver balls continued for a considerable time, the low murmur of the crowd punctuated by the quiet rustle of cloth and the occasional soft clink of a ball.

Once the sortition was complete and the initial body of electors identified, the entire assembly was directed to move. We followed the stream of nobles into an adjacent chamber, the Sala dello Scrutinio. It was decorated in a similar style to the main hall, though it was noticeably smaller, and indeed, less crowded, now that only the electors and essential officials remained. The atmosphere here was markedly different; the boisterous hubbub of the Great Council had given way to a more subdued, serious air, befitting the gravity of the task at hand.

The newly selected electors, along with those who held the right by office, filed in one by one. Each, as they entered, executed profound bows, almost to the ground, before those already seated. It was a display of "gravity without parallel," a silent acknowledgement of the weight of their collective responsibility, a ritualized humility that struck me as particularly Venetian.

After this solemn procession concluded, the Grand Chancellor made his entrance, heralded by a retinue of secretaries. These were subordinate officials, clad in their simpler black togas, moving with a quiet efficiency. The Chancellor himself, a figure of imposing stature, preceded a most important personage: the Vice-Doge. The true Doge, as we knew, was indisposed by illness, and his functions were temporarily assumed by the oldest of the ducal councillors. He did not, of course, sit upon the true Doge's throne, nor did he wear the distinctive *corno*, the ducal cap. Yet, he strove to embody the dignity of the office as best he could. On his head, he wore his black taffeta barrette, its peak pulled forward in a manner that, to my eyes, resembled the Phrygian cap, giving him the appearance of some ancient, venerable Antenor.

He was attended by the other councillors, all in their striking red robes, their presence lending an additional splash of colour and authority to the scene. As the Vice-Doge appeared at the entrance, the entire assembly rose in unison, a ripple of black and red across the benches. He returned their greeting with a deep bow, his eyes sweeping across the room. He did not remove his barrette, however, except for a singular gesture: as he passed before the bench of the Criminal Quarantia, he briefly doffed his cap, a unique mark of deference to that powerful judicial body. It was a subtle but telling detail, indicating the intricate hierarchy and the specific powers that commanded respect even from the Doge's temporary proxy. He alone, of all present, kept his head covered otherwise.

The Vice-Doge then ascended the dais and took his place, not on the Doge's throne, but on a more modest seat beside it. The Sages, the Grandi, and other high officials arranged themselves around him, forming a semicircle of authority. The Chancellor positioned himself on one of the wings, at the head of his secretaries. The assembly, now fully constituted and formally seated, truly possessed an air of majesty, a stark contrast to the initial chaotic hubbub of the larger hall.

The Chancellor, having settled, rose once more. His voice, clear and resonant, cut through the expectant silence as he announced the names of the noblemen who sought the important charge of General of the Galleys: "The Most Excellent Lords Priuli, Badoar, Donato, and Vendramini." No sooner had the names been spoken than a rustle went through the assembly. Immediately, those close relatives of the candidates present in the hall rose from their seats and quietly exited. This was a well-known custom, a measure to prevent any appearance of family influence or undue pressure in the voting process.

As they departed, the three *Avvogadori*, the State Attorneys, stepped forward. These solemn figures, guardians of the Republic's laws, each held a small, leather-bound Gospel. With grave faces, they began to circulate among the seated electors, extending the small book to each man. Every noble, in turn, touched the Gospel with the tip of his finger, a silent but binding oath. This was the solemn pledge to proceed with the election in good faith, "sans brigue" – without intrigue, without corruption. I couldn't help but recall the story of Tiepolo and Aimo, and the elaborate deceptions they employed, and wondered how many of these solemn oaths were merely for show in a city where politicking was an art form.

With these essential preliminaries concluded, a new figure entered the fray: a large, "porpoise-like" usher. He was a man of considerable girth, with a nose that seemed to contend for size with the monstrous spectacles perched upon it. He cleared his throat and, in a remarkably nasal tone, boomed out the name of the first candidate: "The Most Excellent Lord Luca Priuli!"

At once, as if on cue, a flurry of activity erupted. About twenty small boys, dressed in distinct red tunics – "like those from the hospital," as I observed – scattered through the hall. They were the *Ballottini*, and they cried out, almost frantically, "Priuli! Priuli!" as they moved among the nobles. Each boy carried a small wooden box, or *bussola*, divided into two compartments: one marked white, for "yes," and the other green, for "no." The opening was cleverly funnel-shaped, ensuring that no one could observe into which compartment a noble placed his hand. Attached to each boy's belt was a small pouch, a *gibecière*, filled with tiny balls of compressed linen, no larger than shirt buttons – the *balote*.

They distributed one *balota* to each noble, who then, with a hand concealed by the funnel, dropped it into the compartment of his choice. The secrecy was absolute. Once they had made their rounds, the children, still calling out the candidate's name, converged on the Chancellor. He, in turn, took each *bussola*, carefully poured the *balote* from the white "yes" compartment into a large silver basin, and summarily discarded those from the green "no" compartment.

This elaborate dance was repeated for each of the other three candidates: Badoar, Vendramini, and finally, Donato. Each time, the usher's booming voice, the children's cries, and the silent, secret casting of votes filled the hall. Once all four had been balloted, the Chancellor, assisted by his secretaries, meticulously counted the suffrages in the silver basin. The tension was palpable as the numbers were tallied.

Finally, the announcement came: Donato had been elected General of the Galleys. And with that, the formal proceedings concluded, and we were free to leave.

It had all transpired with a surprising rapidity, far quicker than I could recount it in a letter. But the real spectacle, I thought, unfolded as we exited the palace and mingled with the crowd. It was a true comedy, witnessing the newly elected Donato. He adopted an air of exaggerated humility, bowing profoundly to every well-wisher, his face a mask of grateful deference. And then came the "baisers de nourrice," the effusive, almost maternal kisses he received from his supporters. These were not mere polite pecks; they were loud, resounding smacks that, I swear, could be heard echoing across the very middle of the Piazza San Marco. It was a joyous, almost theatrical display of congratulations, a fitting end to a most singular Venetian election.

Simulation Data Sheet: The Great Council of Venice (1740)


Document Objective

This document serves as a knowledge base for a text-based simulation (LLM). It details the mechanics, atmosphere, and procedures of the Maggior Consiglio (Great Council) in 1740, based on the institutional analysis of Amelot de La Houssaye and historical data regarding the daily life of the Republic.

1. The Space: La Sala del Maggior Consiglio

For the simulation, the space acts as a constraining environment that dictates movement and social interaction.

Architecture and Symbolism

Dimensions: A massive hall (53m x 25m) free of supporting columns, capable of holding between 1,000 and 2,000 patricians.
The Ceiling: Heavy with gold leaf and paintings (notably Veronese’s The Triumph of Venice). It serves as a constant reminder of the divine and state hierarchy.
The East Wall (Il Paradiso): Dominated by Tintoretto’s immense canvas, located above the Signoria's tribune. By 1740, the painting had darkened with time, creating a severe backdrop behind the Doge.
The Tribune (La Signoria): A raised platform where the Doge, his six counselors, and the three chiefs of the Quarantia sit. They physically overlook the assembly.
The Benches (Banchi): Arranged in double rows parallel to the walls, leaving a vast central aisle empty for voting procedures.1

Annexed Spaces (Crucial for Intrigue)

The Liagò: A closed loggia or terrace adjacent to the hall. It is a "decompression" zone where nobles withdraw to speak freely, negotiate votes away from the Signoria’s gaze, or escape the stifling air of the main hall.2
The Sala dello Scrutinio: An adjacent hall often used for counting votes or secondary balloting procedures.3

Sensory Atmosphere

Acoustics: The sheer volume of the hall and the number of participants create a constant background hum (buzzing). Official readings by the Chancellor are often inaudible to those seated at the far ends.
Light and Temperature: The hall is lit by large windows facing the lagoon. In winter, it is notoriously freezing (nobles keep their fur-lined cloaks on). In summer, the heat and the proximity of bodies make the air oppressive.4

2. The Actors: Patrician Sociology (1740)

The simulation must distinguish between three classes of nobles, who are legally equal but economically and politically divided.

The Three Classes

The "Case Vecchie" and the Rich: Historic families or immense new fortunes. They monopolize high executive offices (Savi, Council of Ten, Ambassadors). They use the Great Council to validate their power, though real decisions are made in the Senate.5
The Middle Nobility: They aim for judicial (Quarantie) and administrative offices. They are often legalistic and attached to procedure.
The Barnabotti (The Noble Plebs):
Definition: Impoverished nobles, often living in the parish of San Barnaba. They have lost their fortunes but retain their vote in the Council.6
Role in Simulation: They constitute an electoral maneuver mass. Barred from trade and manual labor, their only "commodity" is their vote. They are known to be unruly and to sell their suffrage in exchange for informal gratuities (protection, loans, meals).7

Costume (Visual Code)

The Vesta (Toga): Mandatory for all. A long black gown with large sleeves (a comito). In winter, it is lined with fur; in summer, it is made of light silk.9
The Stola (Stole): A band of black cloth worn over the left shoulder. Its width and lining indicate rank (ordinary for a simple noble, wide and fur-lined for Senators and Councilors).10
The Wig: By 1740, the use of the powdered wig is generalized, creating an anachronistic contrast between the medieval costume (toga) and the Rococo hairstyle. High, voluminous wigs are a sign of fashion and wealth.

3. The Political Ritual


Before the Session: The Broglio

Location: The Piazzetta San Marco, before the bell rings.
Action: This is the time for electoral solicitation. Candidates ("solicitors") stand on one side, electors on the other.12
Gestures: Open campaigning is forbidden by law. Everything occurs through codes of exaggerated politeness: deep bows, kissing of the sleeve or stole, and whispered requests for support ("Mi raccomando").12
The Trottiera: The specific bell that announces the imminent start of the session, urging latecomers to hasten to the palace.4

During the Session: Voting and Chance

The Venetian system, detailed by Amelot de La Houssaye, relies on a complex mix of Sortition (to prevent factions) and Election (to ensure competence).

The Tools

The Ballottino: A boy aged 8 to 10, often dressed in white, tasked with drawing balls from the urns to guarantee the innocence of chance.3
The Bussole (Urns): Wooden structures allowing for secret voting. The noble inserts his hand and drops his ball into a hidden tube (the "Yes" tube or "No" tube).
The Balls (Balote): Small balls made of compressed linen (for silence).
Gold: Winning ball (for sortition).
Silver: Losing ball.
White / Red (or Green): Used for voting "Yes" or "No" during legislative or judicial scrutinies.3

The "Four Hands" Procedure (Election of Magistrates)

This is the standard procedure for electing state officials.14
The Sortition: Each noble passes before an urn. The Ballottino draws a ball for him. If he gets a Gold ball, he becomes an Elector. This continues until 36 electors are chosen.14
The Division: The 36 electors are isolated and divided into 4 groups of 9, called "Hands" (Mani).
The Nomination (Secret): Each "Hand," isolated in a separate room, must agree (by a majority of 6 out of 9) to propose one candidate for the vacant post.
The General Ballot: The 4 names proposed (one by each "Hand") are announced to the Great Council. The entire assembly then votes for or against each candidate. The one with the most votes wins.14

4. Simulation Data Cards


Card A: Sequence of Actions (Sunday Routine)

10:00 AM - Broglio: Social interaction on the Piazza. Informal negotiations.
10:30 AM - Trottiera: Sound signal. Crowd movement towards the Giants' Staircase.
11:00 AM - Installation: Entry into the hall. Barnabotti seek strategic seats or cluster together.
11:30 AM - Reading: The Chancellor reads the list of vacant posts. Ambient hubbub.
12:00 PM - Lottery (Ballottino): Slow procession before the urn. Tension of the Gold/Silver draw.
1:00 PM - Conclave of the 4 Hands: Session suspension for the 36 electors. Others wait, chat in the Liagò.
2:00 PM - Final Vote: Procession to the Bussole to validate candidates.

Card B: Tension Variables

These modifiers can be used to generate incidents or intrigues in the simulation.
Cold/Heat: Impatience factor. Can push nobles to rush a vote or leave the session early (if the quorum is not threatened).
Vote Selling: A player may be approached by an agent of a rich family: "A dinner invitation in exchange for a white ball for candidate Cornaro."6
Procedural Error: If the Ballottino makes a mistake or an urn is improperly closed, the Quarantie (judges) must intervene, creating a dramatic interruption.

[HOW TO USE]: Here is the event text that must be augmented. It comes from Charles de Brosses's "Lettres familières d'Italie". Please bridge the gaps between the events that de Brosses describes in a plausible way.
On nous fit la faveur de nous faire entrer au Grand Conseil pour voir l'élection du général des galères, charge assez importante. Le Grand Conseil se tient dans une salle immense et bien ornée. Dans le fond est une estrade où sont les places des conseillers et des inquisiteurs d'État, avec le trône du doge au milieu. L'estrade surbaissée tourne tout autour de la salle, et de longs rangs de bancs adossés les uns aux autres et rangés en allées remplissent la salle. Tous les nobles entrèrent là sans ordre et se placèrent. Les robes rouges avoient leurs places marquées, et quelques-unes se dispersèrent en différents lieux de la salle, pour empêcher qu'il ne se fît du bruit dans une si nombreuse assemblée; chose, à mon gré, où ils ne réussirent nullement, puisque l'on y faisoit un sabbat de l'autre monde; aussi ne faisoit-on là que peloter en attendant partie.

Près du grand chancelier, sur l'estrade, il y avoit une urne contenant autant de petites boules qu'il y avoit de personnes, et parmi ces boules un certain nombre de dorées ; chacun tira la sienne. Ceux à qui échurent celles dorées furent les électeurs de la charge en question, avec une grande quantité d'autres qui, par leurs places, étoient électeurs de droit.

Cela fait, nous passâmes dans la salle du scrutin, ornée de la même manière que la première, moins grande, remplie de bancs, l'assemblée y étant moins nombreuse. Les autres électeurs entrèrent l'un après l'autre, saluant jusqu'à terre les précédents, avec une gravité sans pareille. Dès qu'ils eurent tous défilé, le chancelier parut, précédé du corps des secrétaires, gens subalternes, et précédant lui-même le vice-doge; car le doge étoit malade, et c'est le plus vieux des conseillers qui le représente. Mais il ne s'assied pas sur le trône et n'a pas le corno; il l'imitoit tant qu'il pouvoit, ayant mis sur sa tête sa barrette ou bonnet de taffetas noir, dont il ramenoit le sommet par devant en bec à la phrygienne, comme un véritable Anténor. Il étoit suivi de tous les conseillers en robes rouges. Dès qu'il parut, toute l'assemblée se leva; il la salua profondément, sans ôter sa barrette que pour la Quarantie criminelle, lorsqu'il passa devant elle. Seul, de toute l'assemblée, il l'avoit sur la tête.

Il monta sur l'estrade et s'assit. Les sages, grands et autres, se placèrent autour de lui, et sur les ailes le chancelier, à la tête des secrétaires, dont il est le chef. Cette assemblée avoit l'air tout à fait majestueux.

Alors le chancelier se leva et dit que les seigneurs Priuli, Badoar, Donato et Vendramini demandoient la charge en question. Sur-le-champ leurs parents proches se levèrent et sortirent. Immédiatement après, les trois avvogadori prirent chacun un petit évangile, et parcoururent les rangs en faisant toucher à chacun cet évangile du bout du doigt, marque du serment de procéder à l'élection de bonne foi et sans brigue.

Tous ces préalables finis, un grand marsouin d'huissier, ayant mis une paire de lunettes monstrueuses sur un nez qui l'étoit davantage, proclama d'un ton nasillard : « Vexcellentissimo signore Luca Priuli. » À l'instant, une vingtaine de petits enfants rouges, comme ceux de l'hôpital, se dispersèrent par la salle, criant comme des perdus : « Priuli ! Priuli ! » Ils avoient chacun à la main une boîte à deux compartiments, l'un blanc pour nommer, l'autre vert pour refuser; l'ouverture commune étant faite en entonnoir, afin que les assistants ne puissent voir dans laquelle des deux divisions on met la main, et à la ceinture une gibecière pleine de petites ballottes comme des boutons de chemisette; ils en donnèrent une à chaque noble. Ceux-ci la mirent dans celle des enchâtres (compartiments) qu'ils voulurent. Les enfants portèrent leurs boîtes au chancelier, qui versa les ballottes des enchâtres blanches dans un bassin, et jeta les autres. On ballotta de même les trois autres concurrents; puis on compta les suffrages. Donato fut élu, et nous sortîmes.

Tout cela fut fait avec une rapidité surprenante, et en moins de temps qu'il n'y en a que je vous en écris; mais c'étoit une vraie comédie que de voir, en sortant, les prosternations de Donato et les baisers de nourrice qu'on lui donnoit. D'honneur, ils sonnoient à se faire entendre au milieu de la place.

documents.content:
The French Ambassador, the Comte de Froulay, had proven himself an invaluable resource during our sojourn in Venice, a true balm against the frequent ennui of foreign lands. It was through his good offices, and perhaps a well-placed word or two, that we received the singular favour of witnessing a session of the Great Council. The opportunity to observe the very engine of this ancient Republic, to see the patricians in their element, was one not to be missed.

The morning of the election for the General of the Galleys dawned crisp but clear, a typical late summer day in Venice. We took a gondola, not one of the Republic’s gilded vessels, but a modest black one, to the Piazzetta San Marco. Even before the *Trottiera* bell, the square was a hive of activity, a spectacle in itself. Nobles in their black *vesta* and *stola*, their powdered wigs bobbing, moved through the arcades of the Procuratie, engaging in what was known as the *broglio*. Despite the laws against overt campaigning, the air thrummed with hushed conversations, deep bows, and discreet handshakes. I observed men leaning close, murmuring "Mi raccomando" – "I recommend myself" – a subtle plea for favour, a dance of exaggerated politeness that belied the fierce political maneuvering beneath. One could almost feel the currents of influence and ambition swirling around the ancient columns.

As the *Trottiera* bell began its resonant peal, a gentle but insistent clang, the crowd began to coalesce, flowing towards the Giants' Staircase of the Doge's Palace. We followed the stream of black-robed figures, ascending the grand marble steps, themselves a testament to Venice's enduring power. Inside, the antechambers were already bustling, filled with nobles shaking off the last vestiges of their Piazzetta intrigues, adjusting their stoles, and exchanging final, hurried words.

Finally, we were ushered into the Sala del Maggior Consiglio. The sheer scale of the hall was breathtaking, a cavernous space stretching some fifty paces in length and half that in width, utterly devoid of supporting columns. My gaze was immediately drawn upwards to the magnificent ceiling, heavy with gold leaf and the vibrant, triumphant scenes painted by Veronese, a stark contrast to the rather severe backdrop of Tintoretto’s immense *Il Paradiso* on the eastern wall, which loomed, darkened by centuries, behind the Doge’s tribune. Despite the grandeur, the hall struck me as somewhat ponderous, a relic of an earlier age, much like the old palaces I had noted elsewhere, magnificent yet often poorly maintained.

The benches, arranged in long, double rows parallel to the walls, were already filling with patricians. They entered without formal procession, finding their seats with a casualness that belied the solemnity of the occasion. The "red robes"—those of the Senators and high magistrates—had their designated places, though some, charged perhaps with maintaining order, dispersed themselves throughout the vast assembly. Yet, even with their presence, the hall was far from silent. A constant, low hum of conversation, punctuated by louder exclamations, filled the air. It was, as I noted, a veritable "sabbat de l'autre monde," a clamour that made the Chancellor's eventual pronouncements almost inaudible to those seated at the far ends. Many nobles seemed content to "peloter en attendant partie," merely passing the time with animated chatter, a testament to the Venetian disposition for amusement even amidst affairs of state. I observed the various types: the opulent *Case Vecchie* in their finer furs and wider stoles, their wigs perfectly coiffed; the *Middle Nobility*, more numerous, often engrossed in legalistic discussions; and the *Barnabotti*, identifiable by their slightly worn togas and less fashionable wigs, often clustered together, their animated gestures hinting at the small, whispered transactions of their votes, their only remaining currency. The air, though not stifling, felt thick with the breath of so many bodies, and I was glad for the large windows overlooking the lagoon, though they offered little reprieve from the general din.

Near the grand Chancellor’s station, on the raised estrade that dominated the far end of the hall, an ornate wooden urn stood ready. This was for the first stage of selection, a concession to chance designed to prevent the outright dominance of factions. From this urn, each noble present was to draw a small ball. Among these, a certain number were gilded. I watched the procession begin, a slow, deliberate line of patricians, each approaching the urn with a mixture of anticipation and feigned indifference. A small boy, no older than ten, dressed in a simple white tunic, stood beside the urn, his innocent presence meant to guarantee the impartiality of the draw. This was the *Ballottino*, a charming detail of this unique system. He would present the urn to each man, who would then reach in and retrieve a ball. Whispers rippled through the assembly as gold balls were revealed, signaling the selection of an elector, or silver ones, indicating the noble would remain a mere observer for this stage. Those who drew gold balls joined the ranks of the "electors of right," men whose high offices already granted them a vote in such matters. The process was drawn out, filled with a quiet tension, as fortunes were decided by the simple fall of a ball.

Once this initial sortition was complete, and the chosen electors identified, we were directed to move. The assembly, though still considerable, began to flow towards an adjacent chamber: the Sala dello Scrutinio. It was, as described, similarly ornate to the main hall, though of a somewhat lesser dimension and filled with fewer benches, reflecting the reduced number of participants in this more focused stage of the election. The air here felt a shade more serious, the hum of voices slightly subdued.

The electors, now a select group, entered the Sala dello Scrutinio one by one, each performing a series of profound bows, a "gravité sans pareille," as they acknowledged those already seated. It was a ritual of deference, each noble demonstrating respect for the collective authority of the Council. As the last elector took his place, a hush fell over the room. Then, the Chancellor appeared, a figure of meticulous order. He was preceded by a modest retinue of secretaries, men of diligent service, dressed in their dark robes, carrying bundles of documents. Following the Chancellor, with an air of practiced solemnity, was the Vice-Doge. The Doge himself was, as we knew, indisposed, and it fell to the eldest of the ducal councillors to represent him. The Vice-Doge did not, of course, wear the magnificent *corno*, the ducal cap, nor did he sit upon the true throne. Yet, he imitated the Doge's bearing as best he could, his head adorned with his own black taffeta *barrette*, its peak drawn forward into a Phrygian shape, giving him the appearance of an ancient Antenor. He was flanked by the other councillors, all in their distinctive red robes, their presence adding a splash of colour to the predominantly black assembly. As this dignitary entered, the entire assembly rose in a unified motion. He returned their respect with a deep bow, his *barrette* remaining firmly on his head, only to remove it in a specific gesture of acknowledgement as he passed before the *Quarantia criminale*, the high court of justice, a testament to their unique authority. He alone, of the entire assembly, kept his cap on his head throughout.

He ascended the estrade and took his seat, not on the Doge’s empty throne, but in a prominent chair beside it. Around him, the *Savi*, the *Grands*, and other high magistrates settled into their places, forming a formidable semicircle. On the wings of this elevated platform, the Chancellor positioned himself at the head of his secretaries, overseeing their preparations. The collective presence of these powerful figures, all in their official attire, imbued the assembly with an undeniable air of majesty, a tangible sense of the Republic’s enduring authority.

The Chancellor rose again, his voice cutting through the remaining murmurs with official gravity. He announced the candidates for the important charge of General of the Galleys: "the illustrious lords Priuli, Badoar, Donato, and Vendramini." Immediately, as per Venetian custom, a ripple of movement spread through the room. The close relatives of each named candidate rose from their benches and quietly exited the chamber. This was a protocol strictly observed, designed to prevent any overt display of family influence or pressure during the crucial vote. The act, though seemingly simple, underscored the Republic's constant vigilance against the very factions it simultaneously relied upon.

No sooner had the relatives departed than three *Avvogadori* stepped forward. These were the state attorneys, guardians of the Republic's laws. Each held a small Gospel in his hand, bound in dark leather. With solemn faces, they moved through the rows of nobles, presenting the sacred text. Each patrician, in turn, touched the Gospel with the tip of his finger, a ritualistic gesture signifying his oath to proceed with the election in good faith, free from "brigue"—from any undue influence or corrupt solicitation. The air grew heavy with the weight of this collective pledge, a moment of profound, if perhaps often ignored, moral commitment.

With all these preliminaries concluded, a towering figure emerged, an usher of impressive girth whom I mentally dubbed a "great porpoise." He adjusted a pair of monstrous spectacles upon a nose that was, if anything, even more imposing, and then, in a surprisingly nasal, almost whiny tone, he proclaimed: "Vexcellentissimo signore Luca Priuli!" At his pronouncement, a sudden burst of energy filled the room. From the antechambers, a score of small boys, dressed in bright red tunics—much like those worn by the orphans in the city’s *ospedali*—scampered into the hall. They darted among the benches, crying out, "Priuli! Priuli!" with an almost frantic enthusiasm. Each child carried a small wooden box, a *bussola*, divided into two compartments: one painted white for "yes," the other green for "no." The common opening was shaped like a funnel, cleverly designed to conceal which compartment a noble chose. At their belts, each *Ballottino* carried a small pouch, a *gibecière*, filled with tiny balls, no larger than shirt buttons, crafted from compressed linen to ensure silent voting. They handed one of these *ballotte* to each noble. The patricians, in turn, with varying degrees of deliberation, dropped their ball into the chosen compartment of the *bussola*. The children, once their boxes were filled, scurried back to the Chancellor, who, with a practiced motion, emptied the *ballotte* from the white compartment into a large silver basin, discarding the green ones.

The same process was then meticulously repeated for each of the other three candidates: Badoar, Vendramini, and finally, Donato. Each time, the usher’s nasally voice would announce the name, the red-clad children would scatter with their cries, and the nobles would cast their silent votes. The rhythm was swift, almost mechanical, yet punctuated by the subtle tension of individual decisions. Once all four candidates had been balloted, the Chancellor, with the aid of his secretaries, began the final count of the suffrages. The room was now quieter, a collective breath held in anticipation. Finally, the result was announced: Donato was elected.

The moment the name was declared, the formal solemnity that had governed the proceedings shattered. We were ushered out, but even as we departed, the scene transformed into a veritable "comédie." Donato, the newly elected General of the Galleys, was immediately surrounded by an eager throng of well-wishers. He received their congratulations with an almost theatrical humility, bowing deeply, performing "prosternations" that seemed to scrape the very floor. The air was filled with robust slaps on the back and loud, effusive "baisers de nourrice"—kisses on the cheek, delivered with a hearty, almost maternal fervour. The sounds of their booming congratulations, I swear, were loud enough to carry across the Piazzetta, a boisterous affirmation of a successful political manoeuvre, or perhaps simply the genuine joy of a party's triumph. It all unfolded with a surprising rapidity, a testament to the efficient, if idiosyncratic, machinery of Venetian governance, leaving me with a vivid impression of its unique blend of ancient ritual, calculated intrigue, and unbridled human expression.

Simulation Data Sheet: The Great Council of Venice (1740)


Document Objective

This document serves as a knowledge base for a text-based simulation (LLM). It details the mechanics, atmosphere, and procedures of the Maggior Consiglio (Great Council) in 1740, based on the institutional analysis of Amelot de La Houssaye and historical data regarding the daily life of the Republic.

1. The Space: La Sala del Maggior Consiglio

For the simulation, the space acts as a constraining environment that dictates movement and social interaction.

Architecture and Symbolism

Dimensions: A massive hall (53m x 25m) free of supporting columns, capable of holding between 1,000 and 2,000 patricians.
The Ceiling: Heavy with gold leaf and paintings (notably Veronese’s The Triumph of Venice). It serves as a constant reminder of the divine and state hierarchy.
The East Wall (Il Paradiso): Dominated by Tintoretto’s immense canvas, located above the Signoria's tribune. By 1740, the painting had darkened with time, creating a severe backdrop behind the Doge.
The Tribune (La Signoria): A raised platform where the Doge, his six counselors, and the three chiefs of the Quarantia sit. They physically overlook the assembly.
The Benches (Banchi): Arranged in double rows parallel to the walls, leaving a vast central aisle empty for voting procedures.1

Annexed Spaces (Crucial for Intrigue)

The Liagò: A closed loggia or terrace adjacent to the hall. It is a "decompression" zone where nobles withdraw to speak freely, negotiate votes away from the Signoria’s gaze, or escape the stifling air of the main hall.2
The Sala dello Scrutinio: An adjacent hall often used for counting votes or secondary balloting procedures.3

Sensory Atmosphere

Acoustics: The sheer volume of the hall and the number of participants create a constant background hum (buzzing). Official readings by the Chancellor are often inaudible to those seated at the far ends.
Light and Temperature: The hall is lit by large windows facing the lagoon. In winter, it is notoriously freezing (nobles keep their fur-lined cloaks on). In summer, the heat and the proximity of bodies make the air oppressive.4

2. The Actors: Patrician Sociology (1740)

The simulation must distinguish between three classes of nobles, who are legally equal but economically and politically divided.

The Three Classes

The "Case Vecchie" and the Rich: Historic families or immense new fortunes. They monopolize high executive offices (Savi, Council of Ten, Ambassadors). They use the Great Council to validate their power, though real decisions are made in the Senate.5
The Middle Nobility: They aim for judicial (Quarantie) and administrative offices. They are often legalistic and attached to procedure.
The Barnabotti (The Noble Plebs):
Definition: Impoverished nobles, often living in the parish of San Barnaba. They have lost their fortunes but retain their vote in the Council.6
Role in Simulation: They constitute an electoral maneuver mass. Barred from trade and manual labor, their only "commodity" is their vote. They are known to be unruly and to sell their suffrage in exchange for informal gratuities (protection, loans, meals).7

Costume (Visual Code)

The Vesta (Toga): Mandatory for all. A long black gown with large sleeves (a comito). In winter, it is lined with fur; in summer, it is made of light silk.9
The Stola (Stole): A band of black cloth worn over the left shoulder. Its width and lining indicate rank (ordinary for a simple noble, wide and fur-lined for Senators and Councilors).10
The Wig: By 1740, the use of the powdered wig is generalized, creating an anachronistic contrast between the medieval costume (toga) and the Rococo hairstyle. High, voluminous wigs are a sign of fashion and wealth.

3. The Political Ritual


Before the Session: The Broglio

Location: The Piazzetta San Marco, before the bell rings.
Action: This is the time for electoral solicitation. Candidates ("solicitors") stand on one side, electors on the other.12
Gestures: Open campaigning is forbidden by law. Everything occurs through codes of exaggerated politeness: deep bows, kissing of the sleeve or stole, and whispered requests for support ("Mi raccomando").12
The Trottiera: The specific bell that announces the imminent start of the session, urging latecomers to hasten to the palace.4

During the Session: Voting and Chance

The Venetian system, detailed by Amelot de La Houssaye, relies on a complex mix of Sortition (to prevent factions) and Election (to ensure competence).

The Tools

The Ballottino: A boy aged 8 to 10, often dressed in white, tasked with drawing balls from the urns to guarantee the innocence of chance.3
The Bussole (Urns): Wooden structures allowing for secret voting. The noble inserts his hand and drops his ball into a hidden tube (the "Yes" tube or "No" tube).
The Balls (Balote): Small balls made of compressed linen (for silence).
Gold: Winning ball (for sortition).
Silver: Losing ball.
White / Red (or Green): Used for voting "Yes" or "No" during legislative or judicial scrutinies.3

The "Four Hands" Procedure (Election of Magistrates)

This is the standard procedure for electing state officials.14
The Sortition: Each noble passes before an urn. The Ballottino draws a ball for him. If he gets a Gold ball, he becomes an Elector. This continues until 36 electors are chosen.14
The Division: The 36 electors are isolated and divided into 4 groups of 9, called "Hands" (Mani).
The Nomination (Secret): Each "Hand," isolated in a separate room, must agree (by a majority of 6 out of 9) to propose one candidate for the vacant post.
The General Ballot: The 4 names proposed (one by each "Hand") are announced to the Great Council. The entire assembly then votes for or against each candidate. The one with the most votes wins.14

4. Simulation Data Cards


Card A: Sequence of Actions (Sunday Routine)

10:00 AM - Broglio: Social interaction on the Piazza. Informal negotiations.
10:30 AM - Trottiera: Sound signal. Crowd movement towards the Giants' Staircase.
11:00 AM - Installation: Entry into the hall. Barnabotti seek strategic seats or cluster together.
11:30 AM - Reading: The Chancellor reads the list of vacant posts. Ambient hubbub.
12:00 PM - Lottery (Ballottino): Slow procession before the urn. Tension of the Gold/Silver draw.
1:00 PM - Conclave of the 4 Hands: Session suspension for the 36 electors. Others wait, chat in the Liagò.
2:00 PM - Final Vote: Procession to the Bussole to validate candidates.

Card B: Tension Variables

These modifiers can be used to generate incidents or intrigues in the simulation.
Cold/Heat: Impatience factor. Can push nobles to rush a vote or leave the session early (if the quorum is not threatened).
Vote Selling: A player may be approached by an agent of a rich family: "A dinner invitation in exchange for a white ball for candidate Cornaro."6
Procedural Error: If the Ballottino makes a mistake or an urn is improperly closed, the Quarantie (judges) must intervene, creating a dramatic interruption.

[HOW TO USE]: Here is the event text that must be augmented. It comes from Charles de Brosses's "Lettres familières d'Italie". Please bridge the gaps between the events that de Brosses describes in a plausible way.
On nous fit la faveur de nous faire entrer au Grand Conseil pour voir l'élection du général des galères, charge assez importante. Le Grand Conseil se tient dans une salle immense et bien ornée. Dans le fond est une estrade où sont les places des conseillers et des inquisiteurs d'État, avec le trône du doge au milieu. L'estrade surbaissée tourne tout autour de la salle, et de longs rangs de bancs adossés les uns aux autres et rangés en allées remplissent la salle. Tous les nobles entrèrent là sans ordre et se placèrent. Les robes rouges avoient leurs places marquées, et quelques-unes se dispersèrent en différents lieux de la salle, pour empêcher qu'il ne se fît du bruit dans une si nombreuse assemblée; chose, à mon gré, où ils ne réussirent nullement, puisque l'on y faisoit un sabbat de l'autre monde; aussi ne faisoit-on là que peloter en attendant partie.

Près du grand chancelier, sur l'estrade, il y avoit une urne contenant autant de petites boules qu'il y avoit de personnes, et parmi ces boules un certain nombre de dorées ; chacun tira la sienne. Ceux à qui échurent celles dorées furent les électeurs de la charge en question, avec une grande quantité d'autres qui, par leurs places, étoient électeurs de droit.

Cela fait, nous passâmes dans la salle du scrutin, ornée de la même manière que la première, moins grande, remplie de bancs, l'assemblée y étant moins nombreuse. Les autres électeurs entrèrent l'un après l'autre, saluant jusqu'à terre les précédents, avec une gravité sans pareille. Dès qu'ils eurent tous défilé, le chancelier parut, précédé du corps des secrétaires, gens subalternes, et précédant lui-même le vice-doge; car le doge étoit malade, et c'est le plus vieux des conseillers qui le représente. Mais il ne s'assied pas sur le trône et n'a pas le corno; il l'imitoit tant qu'il pouvoit, ayant mis sur sa tête sa barrette ou bonnet de taffetas noir, dont il ramenoit le sommet par devant en bec à la phrygienne, comme un véritable Anténor. Il étoit suivi de tous les conseillers en robes rouges. Dès qu'il parut, toute l'assemblée se leva; il la salua profondément, sans ôter sa barrette que pour la Quarantie criminelle, lorsqu'il passa devant elle. Seul, de toute l'assemblée, il l'avoit sur la tête.

Il monta sur l'estrade et s'assit. Les sages, grands et autres, se placèrent autour de lui, et sur les ailes le chancelier, à la tête des secrétaires, dont il est le chef. Cette assemblée avoit l'air tout à fait majestueux.

Alors le chancelier se leva et dit que les seigneurs Priuli, Badoar, Donato et Vendramini demandoient la charge en question. Sur-le-champ leurs parents proches se levèrent et sortirent. Immédiatement après, les trois avvogadori prirent chacun un petit évangile, et parcoururent les rangs en faisant toucher à chacun cet évangile du bout du doigt, marque du serment de procéder à l'élection de bonne foi et sans brigue.

Tous ces préalables finis, un grand marsouin d'huissier, ayant mis une paire de lunettes monstrueuses sur un nez qui l'étoit davantage, proclama d'un ton nasillard : « Vexcellentissimo signore Luca Priuli. » À l'instant, une vingtaine de petits enfants rouges, comme ceux de l'hôpital, se dispersèrent par la salle, criant comme des perdus : « Priuli ! Priuli ! » Ils avoient chacun à la main une boîte à deux compartiments, l'un blanc pour nommer, l'autre vert pour refuser; l'ouverture commune étant faite en entonnoir, afin que les assistants ne puissent voir dans laquelle des deux divisions on met la main, et à la ceinture une gibecière pleine de petites ballottes comme des boutons de chemisette; ils en donnèrent une à chaque noble. Ceux-ci la mirent dans celle des enchâtres (compartiments) qu'ils voulurent. Les enfants portèrent leurs boîtes au chancelier, qui versa les ballottes des enchâtres blanches dans un bassin, et jeta les autres. On ballotta de même les trois autres concurrents; puis on compta les suffrages. Donato fut élu, et nous sortîmes.

Tout cela fut fait avec une rapidité surprenante, et en moins de temps qu'il n'y en a que je vous en écris; mais c'étoit une vraie comédie que de voir, en sortant, les prosternations de Donato et les baisers de nourrice qu'on lui donnoit. D'honneur, ils sonnoient à se faire entendre au milieu de la place.

documents.content:
The Doge was still ailing, confined to his private apartments within the palace, a point of constant, if hushed, discussion amongst the populace. Yet, the Republic's machinery ground on, indifferent to the health of its figurehead. It was through the kindness of our ambassador, a man ever keen to display the singular workings of this aquatic city, that we found ourselves granted the rare privilege of observing a session of the Great Council. This was not a mere spectacle for foreign eyes, but the very heart of Venetian governance, a chance to witness the election of the *Général des Galères*, a post of no small consequence to this maritime power.

The journey to the Doge's Palace, across the Piazzetta, was itself a transition from the vibrant chaos of San Marco, where merchants hawked their wares and masked figures still mingled despite the season, to the solemnity of state. We ascended the Giants' Staircase, its massive marble figures seeming to silently judge our passage, and passed through the antechambers, already thick with the scent of old wood, beeswax, and damp stone. The air grew perceptibly cooler as we approached the vast *Sala del Maggior Consiglio*, a stark contrast to the oppressive August heat outside.

Upon entering, the sheer scale of the hall was overwhelming. It was immense, far grander than any royal salon I had yet seen, adorned with such a profusion of gold leaf and canvas that the eye struggled to settle. Veronese’s *The Triumph of Venice* blazed above, while Tintoretto’s darkened *Il Paradiso* loomed over the Doge’s tribune at the far end, a severe backdrop to the proceedings. Despite the artistic grandeur, the first impression was one of ordered disorder. Long rows of benches, parallel to the walls, filled the hall, but the nobles, perhaps a thousand or more, seemed to flow in without a prescribed pattern, finding their seats with a casualness that belied the gravity of the occasion. We were directed to a discreet gallery, from where we could observe without impeding the flow.

The hall was already a cauldron of sound, a constant, low hum that De Brosses later described as a "sabbat de l'autre monde." It was less a roar and more a thousand individual conversations, whispers, and rustles of black silk togas, creating an acoustic blur that made any single voice indistinguishable. The nobles, clad in their mandated black *veste* and powdered wigs – a curious blend of medieval costume and rococo fashion – appeared a monochrome sea, broken only by the splashes of red worn by the higher magistrates, the *Savi* and *Consiglieri*. These "robes rouges" did indeed attempt to impose order, dispersing themselves throughout the assembly, their wider, fur-lined *stole* marking their rank, yet their efforts seemed largely in vain. One could discern the Barnabotti, those impoverished nobles from San Barnaba, clustered together, their togas perhaps a little more threadbare than the others, their animated whispers suggesting not just idle chatter but perhaps the quiet negotiation of votes, their only remaining commodity. They were, as I had learned, a crucial electoral mass, easily swayed by the promise of a dinner or a small loan. It was, as De Brosses aptly noted, a kind of "peloter en attendant partie" – a game of political maneuvering and social interaction, played out while awaiting the serious business. The air, despite the hall's size, was warm and thick with the breath of so many bodies, making the prospect of a prolonged session less than inviting.

The session truly began when the Grand Chancellor, a figure of quiet authority, took his place on the raised tribune beside the ornate *Bussole*, a wooden urn for the ballot. A hush, though never complete, fell over the assembly as the first stage of the election commenced: the sortition of electors. A small boy, perhaps eight or ten years old, dressed in a pristine white tunic – the *Ballottino* – stepped forward with an air of practiced solemnity. He was, by tradition, chosen for his innocence, ensuring the impartiality of chance. Each noble, in turn, began a slow procession past the urn. The *Ballottino*, with a delicate hand, drew a small, compressed linen ball for each, presenting it with a serious gaze. The tension was palpable. A gold ball meant selection as an elector; silver meant exclusion from this stage. One could see the subtle shifts in expression as each noble received their fate: relief, disappointment, or perhaps a knowing glance exchanged with a peer, suggesting a pre-arranged strategy. This process, though seemingly random, was a critical filter. Those chosen, along with a significant number of officials who were electors by right of their office, were to form the core group that would ultimately decide the *Général des Galères*.

Once the sortition was complete and the initial group of electors identified, the session was temporarily suspended. The newly selected electors, joined by those already designated by their rank, rose and, with a newfound air of importance, began to move towards an adjacent chamber. We, along with the remaining members of the Great Council who were not part of this specific electoral body, were then ushered into the *Sala dello Scrutinio*. This room, while less gargantuan than the main hall, was still grand, similarly adorned with paintings and furnished with benches, though the assembly here was, as expected, less numerous, concentrating the power in fewer hands.

The atmosphere in the *Sala dello Scrutinio* was noticeably different. The earlier hum and playful chatter had largely dissipated, replaced by a more focused, almost conspiratorial murmur. The electors, now fully aware of their weighty responsibility, entered one by one, performing elaborate, sweeping bows, their powdered wigs nearly sweeping the marble floor, a "gravité sans pareille" that bordered on the theatrical. Each acknowledged the others, a silent dance of deference and political positioning.

Finally, the grand procession that would oversee the election made its entrance. The Chancellor led the way, a formidable figure in his black robes, followed by the body of secretaries, men of lesser rank but essential to the Republic's administration. Behind them came the Vice-Doge, representing the ailing Doge Pisani. He was the eldest of the *Consiglieri*, and though he lacked the Doge's distinctive *corno* (the ducal horn-shaped cap) and could not sit on the Doge's throne, he imitated the supreme magistrate as best he could. On his head, he wore his black taffeta *barrette*, its peak pulled forward in a Phrygian style, giving him, as De Brosses remarked, the appearance of a venerable Antenor. He was flanked by the other *Consiglieri*, all in their striking red robes. As this august group appeared, the entire assembly rose in unison, a ripple of black and red. The Vice-Doge acknowledged them with a profound bow, his *barrette* remaining firmly on his head, only to remove it, with a gesture of deep respect, as he passed before the bench of the *Quarantia criminale*, the powerful criminal court. He alone, of all present, retained his headwear throughout the rest of the ceremony.

He ascended the tribune, taking his place at the center, surrounded by the *Savi grandi* and other high officials. The Chancellor positioned himself on one wing of the tribune, at the head of his secretaries. The assembly, now properly constituted and arranged, did indeed present a majestic sight, a tableau of power and tradition.

The Chancellor then rose once more, his voice, though not loud, cutting through the residual murmurs with official clarity. He announced the candidates for the charge of *Général des Galères*: "The illustrious lords Priuli, Badoar, Donato, and Vendramini request the office in question." Immediately, a discreet stir went through the hall. Close relatives of the named candidates, bound by custom, rose from their seats and quietly exited the chamber, a formality to avoid any perceived conflict of interest or undue influence during the vote.

Following this, three *Avvogadori* – the state prosecutors, guardians of the Republic's laws – stepped forward. Each held a small Gospel, its covers worn smooth by countless oaths. With solemn faces, they moved through the rows of nobles, extending the holy book. Each elector, in turn, touched the Gospel with the tip of their finger, a silent but binding oath to proceed with the election in good faith, free from *brigue* (intrigue or corruption). The contrast between this ancient, sacred ritual and the earlier political horse-trading was striking, a testament to the Venetian blend of piety and pragmatism.

With all preliminaries concluded, a formidable usher, whom De Brosses aptly described as a "grand marsouin," stepped into the central aisle. He was a man of imposing girth, his already prominent nose further magnified by a pair of truly monstrous spectacles perched upon it. His voice, when it came, was a nasal declaration that echoed through the hall: "Vexcellentissimo signore Luca Priuli!"

At this signal, the chamber erupted with a new kind of activity. Some twenty small boys, clad in red tunics "like those from the hospital," burst forth, scattering amongst the rows of nobles. They were the voting assistants, each carrying a small wooden box divided into two compartments: one white for "yes" and one green for "no." The common opening was funnel-shaped, cunningly designed to prevent onlookers from seeing which compartment the noble chose. From small pouches at their belts, filled with tiny linen balls resembling shirt buttons, they offered one to each noble. The nobles, with varying degrees of deliberation, took a ball and, with a swift, hidden motion, dropped it into either the white or green slot. The silence that had briefly descended during the oath was now filled with the soft rustle of robes and the faint, rhythmic click of the *ballotte* falling into the boxes.

The red-clad boys, once their boxes were full, returned to the tribune, presenting them to the Chancellor. With practiced efficiency, he emptied the white balls into a large silver basin, discarding the green ones. This process was repeated for each of the four candidates: Badoar, Vendramini, and finally, Donato. The speed with which these hundreds of individual votes were collected and tallied was indeed surprising, a testament to the efficiency of this unique system.

Finally, the counting began, a tense moment of hushed expectation. The Chancellor's voice, when he finally rose to proclaim the result, was clear and decisive: "The illustrious lord Donato has been elected!"

And with that, the formal proceedings were over. We, along with the remaining observers, began to exit the *Sala dello Scrutinio*, the atmosphere now transformed. The solemnity of the vote gave way to an explosion of congratulatory fervor. It was, as De Brosses observed, a "vraie comédie." Donato, the newly elected *Général des Galères*, was immediately surrounded by a throng of well-wishers. Nobles, his supporters and clients, pressed in, offering deep bows and exuberant embraces. The "baisers de nourrice" – effusive, almost childlike kisses on the cheeks – were delivered with such boisterous enthusiasm that they literally "sonnaient à se faire entendre au milieu de la place," echoing even beyond the palace walls. The sheer theatricality of it all, the swift transition from grave procedure to joyous, almost unrestrained celebration, was a vivid illustration of the Venetian character – a people who conducted their most serious affairs with a flair for the dramatic, and who, even in their political rituals, could not entirely suppress their inherent vivacity. It had all transpired with a surprising rapidity, a whirlwind of ancient custom and contemporary intrigue, leaving an indelible impression of a Republic truly unlike any other.

[HOW TO USE]: Use strictly as historical context. 
Simulation Data Sheet: The Great Council of Venice (1740)


Document Objective

This document serves as a knowledge base for a text-based simulation (LLM). It details the mechanics, atmosphere, and procedures of the Maggior Consiglio (Great Council) in 1740, based on the institutional analysis of Amelot de La Houssaye and historical data regarding the daily life of the Republic.

1. The Space: La Sala del Maggior Consiglio

For the simulation, the space acts as a constraining environment that dictates movement and social interaction.

Architecture and Symbolism

Dimensions: A massive hall (53m x 25m) free of supporting columns, capable of holding between 1,000 and 2,000 patricians.
The Ceiling: Heavy with gold leaf and paintings (notably Veronese’s The Triumph of Venice). It serves as a constant reminder of the divine and state hierarchy.
The East Wall (Il Paradiso): Dominated by Tintoretto’s immense canvas, located above the Signoria's tribune. By 1740, the painting had darkened with time, creating a severe backdrop behind the Doge.
The Tribune (La Signoria): A raised platform where the Doge, his six counselors, and the three chiefs of the Quarantia sit. They physically overlook the assembly.
The Benches (Banchi): Arranged in double rows parallel to the walls, leaving a vast central aisle empty for voting procedures.1

Annexed Spaces (Crucial for Intrigue)

The Liagò: A closed loggia or terrace adjacent to the hall. It is a "decompression" zone where nobles withdraw to speak freely, negotiate votes away from the Signoria’s gaze, or escape the stifling air of the main hall.2
The Sala dello Scrutinio: An adjacent hall often used for counting votes or secondary balloting procedures.3

Sensory Atmosphere

Acoustics: The sheer volume of the hall and the number of participants create a constant background hum (buzzing). Official readings by the Chancellor are often inaudible to those seated at the far ends.
Light and Temperature: The hall is lit by large windows facing the lagoon. In winter, it is notoriously freezing (nobles keep their fur-lined cloaks on). In summer, the heat and the proximity of bodies make the air oppressive.4

2. The Actors: Patrician Sociology (1740)

The simulation must distinguish between three classes of nobles, who are legally equal but economically and politically divided.

The Three Classes

The "Case Vecchie" and the Rich: Historic families or immense new fortunes. They monopolize high executive offices (Savi, Council of Ten, Ambassadors). They use the Great Council to validate their power, though real decisions are made in the Senate.5
The Middle Nobility: They aim for judicial (Quarantie) and administrative offices. They are often legalistic and attached to procedure.
The Barnabotti (The Noble Plebs):
Definition: Impoverished nobles, often living in the parish of San Barnaba. They have lost their fortunes but retain their vote in the Council.6
Role in Simulation: They constitute an electoral maneuver mass. Barred from trade and manual labor, their only "commodity" is their vote. They are known to be unruly and to sell their suffrage in exchange for informal gratuities (protection, loans, meals).7

Costume (Visual Code)

The Vesta (Toga): Mandatory for all. A long black gown with large sleeves (a comito). In winter, it is lined with fur; in summer, it is made of light silk.9
The Stola (Stole): A band of black cloth worn over the left shoulder. Its width and lining indicate rank (ordinary for a simple noble, wide and fur-lined for Senators and Councilors).10
The Wig: By 1740, the use of the powdered wig is generalized, creating an anachronistic contrast between the medieval costume (toga) and the Rococo hairstyle. High, voluminous wigs are a sign of fashion and wealth.

3. The Political Ritual


Before the Session: The Broglio

Location: The Piazzetta San Marco, before the bell rings.
Action: This is the time for electoral solicitation. Candidates ("solicitors") stand on one side, electors on the other.12
Gestures: Open campaigning is forbidden by law. Everything occurs through codes of exaggerated politeness: deep bows, kissing of the sleeve or stole, and whispered requests for support ("Mi raccomando").12
The Trottiera: The specific bell that announces the imminent start of the session, urging latecomers to hasten to the palace.4

During the Session: Voting and Chance

The Venetian system, detailed by Amelot de La Houssaye, relies on a complex mix of Sortition (to prevent factions) and Election (to ensure competence).

The Tools

The Ballottino: A boy aged 8 to 10, often dressed in white, tasked with drawing balls from the urns to guarantee the innocence of chance.3
The Bussole (Urns): Wooden structures allowing for secret voting. The noble inserts his hand and drops his ball into a hidden tube (the "Yes" tube or "No" tube).
The Balls (Balote): Small balls made of compressed linen (for silence).
Gold: Winning ball (for sortition).
Silver: Losing ball.
White / Red (or Green): Used for voting "Yes" or "No" during legislative or judicial scrutinies.3

The "Four Hands" Procedure (Election of Magistrates)

This is the standard procedure for electing state officials.14
The Sortition: Each noble passes before an urn. The Ballottino draws a ball for him. If he gets a Gold ball, he becomes an Elector. This continues until 36 electors are chosen.14
The Division: The 36 electors are isolated and divided into 4 groups of 9, called "Hands" (Mani).
The Nomination (Secret): Each "Hand," isolated in a separate room, must agree (by a majority of 6 out of 9) to propose one candidate for the vacant post.
The General Ballot: The 4 names proposed (one by each "Hand") are announced to the Great Council. The entire assembly then votes for or against each candidate. The one with the most votes wins.14

4. Simulation Data Cards


Card A: Sequence of Actions (Sunday Routine)

10:00 AM - Broglio: Social interaction on the Piazza. Informal negotiations.
10:30 AM - Trottiera: Sound signal. Crowd movement towards the Giants' Staircase.
11:00 AM - Installation: Entry into the hall. Barnabotti seek strategic seats or cluster together.
11:30 AM - Reading: The Chancellor reads the list of vacant posts. Ambient hubbub.
12:00 PM - Lottery (Ballottino): Slow procession before the urn. Tension of the Gold/Silver draw.
1:00 PM - Conclave of the 4 Hands: Session suspension for the 36 electors. Others wait, chat in the Liagò.
2:00 PM - Final Vote: Procession to the Bussole to validate candidates.

Card B: Tension Variables

These modifiers can be used to generate incidents or intrigues in the simulation.
Cold/Heat: Impatience factor. Can push nobles to rush a vote or leave the session early (if the quorum is not threatened).
Vote Selling: A player may be approached by an agent of a rich family: "A dinner invitation in exchange for a white ball for candidate Cornaro."6
Procedural Error: If the Ballottino makes a mistake or an urn is improperly closed, the Quarantie (judges) must intervene, creating a dramatic interruption.

[HOW TO USE]: Here is the event text that must be augmented. It comes from Charles de Brosses's "Lettres familières d'Italie". Please bridge the gaps between the events that de Brosses describes in a plausible way.
On nous fit la faveur de nous faire entrer au Grand Conseil pour voir l'élection du général des galères, charge assez importante. Le Grand Conseil se tient dans une salle immense et bien ornée. Dans le fond est une estrade où sont les places des conseillers et des inquisiteurs d'État, avec le trône du doge au milieu. L'estrade surbaissée tourne tout autour de la salle, et de longs rangs de bancs adossés les uns aux autres et rangés en allées remplissent la salle. Tous les nobles entrèrent là sans ordre et se placèrent. Les robes rouges avoient leurs places marquées, et quelques-unes se dispersèrent en différents lieux de la salle, pour empêcher qu'il ne se fît du bruit dans une si nombreuse assemblée; chose, à mon gré, où ils ne réussirent nullement, puisque l'on y faisoit un sabbat de l'autre monde; aussi ne faisoit-on là que peloter en attendant partie.

Près du grand chancelier, sur l'estrade, il y avoit une urne contenant autant de petites boules qu'il y avoit de personnes, et parmi ces boules un certain nombre de dorées ; chacun tira la sienne. Ceux à qui échurent celles dorées furent les électeurs de la charge en question, avec une grande quantité d'autres qui, par leurs places, étoient électeurs de droit.

Cela fait, nous passâmes dans la salle du scrutin, ornée de la même manière que la première, moins grande, remplie de bancs, l'assemblée y étant moins nombreuse. Les autres électeurs entrèrent l'un après l'autre, saluant jusqu'à terre les précédents, avec une gravité sans pareille. Dès qu'ils eurent tous défilé, le chancelier parut, précédé du corps des secrétaires, gens subalternes, et précédant lui-même le vice-doge; car le doge étoit malade, et c'est le plus vieux des conseillers qui le représente. Mais il ne s'assied pas sur le trône et n'a pas le corno; il l'imitoit tant qu'il pouvoit, ayant mis sur sa tête sa barrette ou bonnet de taffetas noir, dont il ramenoit le sommet par devant en bec à la phrygienne, comme un véritable Anténor. Il étoit suivi de tous les conseillers en robes rouges. Dès qu'il parut, toute l'assemblée se leva; il la salua profondément, sans ôter sa barrette que pour la Quarantie criminelle, lorsqu'il passa devant elle. Seul, de toute l'assemblée, il l'avoit sur la tête.

Il monta sur l'estrade et s'assit. Les sages, grands et autres, se placèrent autour de lui, et sur les ailes le chancelier, à la tête des secrétaires, dont il est le chef. Cette assemblée avoit l'air tout à fait majestueux.

Alors le chancelier se leva et dit que les seigneurs Priuli, Badoar, Donato et Vendramini demandoient la charge en question. Sur-le-champ leurs parents proches se levèrent et sortirent. Immédiatement après, les trois avvogadori prirent chacun un petit évangile, et parcoururent les rangs en faisant toucher à chacun cet évangile du bout du doigt, marque du serment de procéder à l'élection de bonne foi et sans brigue.

Tous ces préalables finis, un grand marsouin d'huissier, ayant mis une paire de lunettes monstrueuses sur un nez qui l'étoit davantage, proclama d'un ton nasillard : « Vexcellentissimo signore Luca Priuli. » À l'instant, une vingtaine de petits enfants rouges, comme ceux de l'hôpital, se dispersèrent par la salle, criant comme des perdus : « Priuli ! Priuli ! » Ils avoient chacun à la main une boîte à deux compartiments, l'un blanc pour nommer, l'autre vert pour refuser; l'ouverture commune étant faite en entonnoir, afin que les assistants ne puissent voir dans laquelle des deux divisions on met la main, et à la ceinture une gibecière pleine de petites ballottes comme des boutons de chemisette; ils en donnèrent une à chaque noble. Ceux-ci la mirent dans celle des enchâtres (compartiments) qu'ils voulurent. Les enfants portèrent leurs boîtes au chancelier, qui versa les ballottes des enchâtres blanches dans un bassin, et jeta les autres. On ballotta de même les trois autres concurrents; puis on compta les suffrages. Donato fut élu, et nous sortîmes.

Tout cela fut fait avec une rapidité surprenante, et en moins de temps qu'il n'y en a que je vous en écris; mais c'étoit une vraie comédie que de voir, en sortant, les prosternations de Donato et les baisers de nourrice qu'on lui donnoit. D'honneur, ils sonnoient à se faire entendre au milieu de la place.
