documents.content:
The favour of an invitation to the Great Council was extended to us, a rare privilege arranged, I suspect, through the good offices of our Ambassador, the Comte de Froulay. To witness the election of the General of the Galleys, a charge of no small importance, was an opportunity not to be missed.

On that particular morning in August, the Piazzetta San Marco was already a hive of activity, even before the Trottiera bell began its insistent summons. Nobles in their black *veste*, many with fur-lined stoles despite the summer heat, moved with a studied nonchalance that barely concealed their underlying purpose. This was the *Broglio*, the outdoor antechamber where votes were subtly solicited. I observed deep bows and whispered conversations, sleeves kissed, and discreet nods exchanged, all part of the intricate dance of Venetian politics. Sainte-Palaye and I, in our foreign attire, stood out somewhat, but our presence was tolerated, even perhaps a curiosity. The air, thick with the scent of the lagoon and the distant murmur of the city, was charged with anticipation.

As the Trottiera rang out, a wave of movement swept through the square. The crowd, a mix of patricians, citizens, and curious onlookers, began to converge towards the Doge's Palace. We followed the stream of black-robed figures, ascending the Giants' Staircase, its grand marble steps worn smooth by centuries of illustrious and ordinary feet. The vastness of the Ducal Palace, with its gothic arches and intricate stonework, seemed to swallow us whole. We passed through several antechambers, already filled with a constant hum of voices, until we reached the Sala del Maggior Consiglio itself.

The hall was indeed immense, a cavernous space stretching fifty-three metres in length and twenty-five in width, capable of holding thousands. My gaze was immediately drawn upwards to the ceiling, a breathtaking expanse heavy with gold leaf and vibrant paintings, Veronese's "The Triumph of Venice" dominating the centre. It was a constant, glorious reminder of the Republic's power and divine favour. Facing us, at the far end, was the east wall, *Il Paradiso*, Tintoretto's colossal canvas, now darkened by time, forming a sombre backdrop behind the raised tribune of the Signoria.

Long rows of wooden benches, arranged in double lines parallel to the walls, filled the vast hall, leaving a wide central aisle. Nobles entered without any apparent order, yet somehow found their places. Those in red robes—the Senators, the Councilors of the Doge, the Chiefs of the Quarantia—occupied specific, marked seats, strategically dispersed, I was told, to exert a semblance of control over the sprawling assembly. A vain effort, to my mind, for the noise that filled the chamber was truly "a sabbath from another world." It was a cacophony of murmurs, greetings, and hushed discussions, a testament to the sheer number of patricians present. Men, some young and eager, others ancient and weary, shifted in their seats, adjusted their voluminous powdered wigs, and conversed freely, seemingly unconcerned by the gravity of the occasion. It was as if they were merely "peloting" – playing a casual game – while awaiting the true contest. The air, despite the high ceilings and large windows overlooking the lagoon, grew heavy and oppressive with the press of so many bodies in their thick robes.

On the raised platform, near the Grand Chancellor, stood an urn. This was the first stage of the election: the sortition. Each noble, in turn, approached the urn, and a small boy, the *Ballottino*, often dressed in white to symbolize his innocence and impartiality, drew a ball for him. A hushed tension fell over the immediate vicinity of the urn as each man reached in. The clatter of the small, silent linen balls was audible. Some drew silver, their faces betraying a flicker of disappointment. Others, a precious few, drew gold, instantly becoming electors for the charge at hand. These were joined by a significant number of others who, by virtue of their existing offices, were electors by right. The drawing seemed to take an age, a slow, deliberate procession before the urn, punctuated by sighs and quiet exclamations.

Once the sortition was complete and the electors identified, we were directed to move to the *Sala dello Scrutinio*, an adjacent hall. It was smaller than the Great Council chamber, but equally well-appointed, though perhaps with a more focused atmosphere. Benches lined this room too, but the assembly here was less numerous, comprising only the chosen electors and those holding offices that granted them the right to vote. The electors entered one by one, a solemn procession, each man bowing profoundly, almost to the ground, to those already seated. This display of "gravity without parallel" was a striking contrast to the earlier chaos.

Soon, the Grand Chancellor appeared, his presence preceded by a retinue of secretaries, junior officials whose black robes and earnest expressions marked their subordinate, yet crucial, role in the Republic's intricate machinery. Behind the Chancellor walked the Vice-Doge, representing the ailing Doge Pisani. He did not sit upon the ducal throne, nor did he wear the distinctive *corno*, the Doge's horn-shaped cap. Yet, he endeavoured to imitate the Doge's bearing as best he could, wearing his black taffeta *barretta*, its peak pulled forward in a Phrygian style, giving him, as I noted, the appearance of a "true Antenor." He was flanked by the red-robed Councilors. As this procession entered, the entire assembly rose in a unified rustle of fabric. The Vice-Doge saluted them with a deep bow, his *barretta* remaining on his head, a mark of his temporary authority. Only when he passed before the *Quarantia Criminale*, the supreme criminal court, did he remove it, a gesture of respect for that ancient and powerful body.

He ascended the estrade and took his seat. Around him, the "Sages, great and other" — the most senior and influential magistrates — settled into their places. The Chancellor, at the head of his secretaries, positioned himself on the wings of the platform. The assembled body, now more concentrated and formal, presented a truly majestic appearance, the red and black robes creating a rich tapestry of power and tradition.

The Chancellor rose again, his voice echoing with a newfound clarity in the slightly smaller hall. He announced the names of the contenders for the post of General of the Galleys: "the seigneurs Priuli, Badoar, Donato, and Vendramini." Immediately, a rustle went through the assembly as the close relatives of these candidates, bound by custom and law, rose from their seats and quietly exited the chamber. This ensured that no family influence, however indirect, could be brought to bear during the ballot.

Next, three *Avvogadori di Comun*—the Republic's public prosecutors, guardians of its laws—stepped forward. Each held a small Gospel. They moved through the ranks of the electors, pausing before each man, who then touched the Gospel with the tip of his finger. This was the solemn oath, a pledge to proceed with the election in good faith, free from "brigue" or undue influence. The ritual was performed with a deliberate, almost theatrical slowness, emphasizing the weight of the moment.

With these preliminaries concluded, a large, corpulent usher, whom I described as a "marsouin" (porpoise), stepped forward. He adjusted a pair of "monstrous" spectacles on his already prominent nose and, with a nasal intonation, proclaimed: "*V'excellentissimo signore Luca Priuli!*" At this cue, a flurry of activity erupted. Some twenty small boys, dressed in red like those from the *Ospedale* (the charitable institutions where orphans were raised), darted into the hall. They cried out, "Priuli! Priuli!" like a flock of lost partridges, their youthful voices a startling contrast to the solemnity that had preceded them. Each boy carried a unique ballot box, a small wooden contraption with two compartments: one white for "yes" (to name the candidate), the other green for "no" (to refuse). A common, funnel-shaped opening ensured that no one could see into which slot a noble placed his hand. Attached to their belts were small pouches, or *gibecières*, filled with tiny balls, the size of shirt buttons.

Each boy offered a ball to every noble. The patricians, with practised ease, took a ball and, after a moment's consideration, placed it into the desired compartment of the box. The boys, once their rounds were complete, carried their boxes back to the Chancellor. He carefully emptied the white balls, representing the "yes" votes, into a large basin, while the green balls, the "no" votes, were discarded. This process was repeated for each of the remaining three candidates.

Finally, the suffrages were counted. The results were announced, and it was Signore Donato who was elected General of the Galleys. The entire procedure, from the initial sortition to the final count, was executed with a "surprising rapidity," completed in far less time than it took me to commit these observations to paper.

As we exited the hall, the scene transformed into a veritable comedy. Donato, the newly elected General, was met with a rush of well-wishers. There were "prosternations" — deep, almost theatrical bows of congratulation — and "baisers de nourrice," effusive, almost maternal kisses that resonated loudly enough, I swear, to be heard in the middle of the Piazza. The gravity of the election quickly gave way to the joyous, and sometimes boisterous, celebration of success, a spectacle of human emotion that, for all its grandness, was undeniably, and amusingly, Venetian.

Simulation Data Sheet: The Great Council of Venice (1740)


Document Objective

This document serves as a knowledge base for a text-based simulation (LLM). It details the mechanics, atmosphere, and procedures of the Maggior Consiglio (Great Council) in 1740, based on the institutional analysis of Amelot de La Houssaye and historical data regarding the daily life of the Republic.

1. The Space: La Sala del Maggior Consiglio

For the simulation, the space acts as a constraining environment that dictates movement and social interaction.

Architecture and Symbolism

Dimensions: A massive hall (53m x 25m) free of supporting columns, capable of holding between 1,000 and 2,000 patricians.
The Ceiling: Heavy with gold leaf and paintings (notably Veronese’s The Triumph of Venice). It serves as a constant reminder of the divine and state hierarchy.
The East Wall (Il Paradiso): Dominated by Tintoretto’s immense canvas, located above the Signoria's tribune. By 1740, the painting had darkened with time, creating a severe backdrop behind the Doge.
The Tribune (La Signoria): A raised platform where the Doge, his six counselors, and the three chiefs of the Quarantia sit. They physically overlook the assembly.
The Benches (Banchi): Arranged in double rows parallel to the walls, leaving a vast central aisle empty for voting procedures.1

Annexed Spaces (Crucial for Intrigue)

The Liagò: A closed loggia or terrace adjacent to the hall. It is a "decompression" zone where nobles withdraw to speak freely, negotiate votes away from the Signoria’s gaze, or escape the stifling air of the main hall.2
The Sala dello Scrutinio: An adjacent hall often used for counting votes or secondary balloting procedures.3

Sensory Atmosphere

Acoustics: The sheer volume of the hall and the number of participants create a constant background hum (buzzing). Official readings by the Chancellor are often inaudible to those seated at the far ends.
Light and Temperature: The hall is lit by large windows facing the lagoon. In winter, it is notoriously freezing (nobles keep their fur-lined cloaks on). In summer, the heat and the proximity of bodies make the air oppressive.4

2. The Actors: Patrician Sociology (1740)

The simulation must distinguish between three classes of nobles, who are legally equal but economically and politically divided.

The Three Classes

The "Case Vecchie" and the Rich: Historic families or immense new fortunes. They monopolize high executive offices (Savi, Council of Ten, Ambassadors). They use the Great Council to validate their power, though real decisions are made in the Senate.5
The Middle Nobility: They aim for judicial (Quarantie) and administrative offices. They are often legalistic and attached to procedure.
The Barnabotti (The Noble Plebs):
Definition: Impoverished nobles, often living in the parish of San Barnaba. They have lost their fortunes but retain their vote in the Council.6
Role in Simulation: They constitute an electoral maneuver mass. Barred from trade and manual labor, their only "commodity" is their vote. They are known to be unruly and to sell their suffrage in exchange for informal gratuities (protection, loans, meals).7

Costume (Visual Code)

The Vesta (Toga): Mandatory for all. A long black gown with large sleeves (a comito). In winter, it is lined with fur; in summer, it is made of light silk.9
The Stola (Stole): A band of black cloth worn over the left shoulder. Its width and lining indicate rank (ordinary for a simple noble, wide and fur-lined for Senators and Councilors).10
The Wig: By 1740, the use of the powdered wig is generalized, creating an anachronistic contrast between the medieval costume (toga) and the Rococo hairstyle. High, voluminous wigs are a sign of fashion and wealth.

3. The Political Ritual


Before the Session: The Broglio

Location: The Piazzetta San Marco, before the bell rings.
Action: This is the time for electoral solicitation. Candidates ("solicitors") stand on one side, electors on the other.12
Gestures: Open campaigning is forbidden by law. Everything occurs through codes of exaggerated politeness: deep bows, kissing of the sleeve or stole, and whispered requests for support ("Mi raccomando").12
The Trottiera: The specific bell that announces the imminent start of the session, urging latecomers to hasten to the palace.4

During the Session: Voting and Chance

The Venetian system, detailed by Amelot de La Houssaye, relies on a complex mix of Sortition (to prevent factions) and Election (to ensure competence).

The Tools

The Ballottino: A boy aged 8 to 10, often dressed in white, tasked with drawing balls from the urns to guarantee the innocence of chance.3
The Bussole (Urns): Wooden structures allowing for secret voting. The noble inserts his hand and drops his ball into a hidden tube (the "Yes" tube or "No" tube).
The Balls (Balote): Small balls made of compressed linen (for silence).
Gold: Winning ball (for sortition).
Silver: Losing ball.
White / Red (or Green): Used for voting "Yes" or "No" during legislative or judicial scrutinies.3

The "Four Hands" Procedure (Election of Magistrates)

This is the standard procedure for electing state officials.14
The Sortition: Each noble passes before an urn. The Ballottino draws a ball for him. If he gets a Gold ball, he becomes an Elector. This continues until 36 electors are chosen.14
The Division: The 36 electors are isolated and divided into 4 groups of 9, called "Hands" (Mani).
The Nomination (Secret): Each "Hand," isolated in a separate room, must agree (by a majority of 6 out of 9) to propose one candidate for the vacant post.
The General Ballot: The 4 names proposed (one by each "Hand") are announced to the Great Council. The entire assembly then votes for or against each candidate. The one with the most votes wins.14

4. Simulation Data Cards


Card A: Sequence of Actions (Sunday Routine)

10:00 AM - Broglio: Social interaction on the Piazza. Informal negotiations.
10:30 AM - Trottiera: Sound signal. Crowd movement towards the Giants' Staircase.
11:00 AM - Installation: Entry into the hall. Barnabotti seek strategic seats or cluster together.
11:30 AM - Reading: The Chancellor reads the list of vacant posts. Ambient hubbub.
12:00 PM - Lottery (Ballottino): Slow procession before the urn. Tension of the Gold/Silver draw.
1:00 PM - Conclave of the 4 Hands: Session suspension for the 36 electors. Others wait, chat in the Liagò.
2:00 PM - Final Vote: Procession to the Bussole to validate candidates.

[HOW TO USE]: Here is the event text that must be augmented. It comes from Charles de Brosses's "Lettres familières d'Italie". Please bridge the gaps between the events that de Brosses describes in a plausible way.
On nous fit la faveur de nous faire entrer au Grand Conseil pour voir l'élection du général des galères, charge assez importante. Le Grand Conseil se tient dans une salle immense et bien ornée. Dans le fond est une estrade où sont les places des conseillers et des inquisiteurs d'État, avec le trône du doge au milieu. L'estrade surbaissée tourne tout autour de la salle, et de longs rangs de bancs adossés les uns aux autres et rangés en allées remplissent la salle. Tous les nobles entrèrent là sans ordre et se placèrent. Les robes rouges avoient leurs places marquées, et quelques-unes se dispersèrent en différents lieux de la salle, pour empêcher qu'il ne se fît du bruit dans une si nombreuse assemblée; chose, à mon gré, où ils ne réussirent nullement, puisque l'on y faisoit un sabbat de l'autre monde; aussi ne faisoit-on là que peloter en attendant partie.

Près du grand chancelier, sur l'estrade, il y avoit une urne contenant autant de petites boules qu'il y avoit de personnes, et parmi ces boules un certain nombre de dorées ; chacun tira la sienne. Ceux à qui échurent celles dorées furent les électeurs de la charge en question, avec une grande quantité d'autres qui, par leurs places, étoient électeurs de droit.

Cela fait, nous passâmes dans la salle du scrutin, ornée de la même manière que la première, moins grande, remplie de bancs, l'assemblée y étant moins nombreuse. Les autres électeurs entrèrent l'un après l'autre, saluant jusqu'à terre les précédents, avec une gravité sans pareille. Dès qu'ils eurent tous défilé, le chancelier parut, précédé du corps des secrétaires, gens subalternes, et précédant lui-même le vice-doge; car le doge étoit malade, et c'est le plus vieux des conseillers qui le représente. Mais il ne s'assied pas sur le trône et n'a pas le corno; il l'imitoit tant qu'il pouvoit, ayant mis sur sa tête sa barrette ou bonnet de taffetas noir, dont il ramenoit le sommet par devant en bec à la phrygienne, comme un véritable Anténor. Il étoit suivi de tous les conseillers en robes rouges. Dès qu'il parut, toute l'assemblée se leva; il la salua profondément, sans ôter sa barrette que pour la Quarantie criminelle, lorsqu'il passa devant elle. Seul, de toute l'assemblée, il l'avoit sur la tête.

Il monta sur l'estrade et s'assit. Les sages, grands et autres, se placèrent autour de lui, et sur les ailes le chancelier, à la tête des secrétaires, dont il est le chef. Cette assemblée avoit l'air tout à fait majestueux.

Alors le chancelier se leva et dit que les seigneurs Priuli, Badoar, Donato et Vendramini demandoient la charge en question. Sur-le-champ leurs parents proches se levèrent et sortirent. Immédiatement après, les trois avvogadori prirent chacun un petit évangile, et parcoururent les rangs en faisant toucher à chacun cet évangile du bout du doigt, marque du serment de procéder à l'élection de bonne foi et sans brigue.

Tous ces préalables finis, un grand marsouin d'huissier, ayant mis une paire de lunettes monstrueuses sur un nez qui l'étoit davantage, proclama d'un ton nasillard : « Vexcellentissimo signore Luca Priuli. » À l'instant, une vingtaine de petits enfants rouges, comme ceux de l'hôpital, se dispersèrent par la salle, criant comme des perdus : « Priuli ! Priuli ! » Ils avoient chacun à la main une boîte à deux compartiments, l'un blanc pour nommer, l'autre vert pour refuser; l'ouverture commune étant faite en entonnoir, afin que les assistants ne puissent voir dans laquelle des deux divisions on met la main, et à la ceinture une gibecière pleine de petites ballottes comme des boutons de chemisette; ils en donnèrent une à chaque noble. Ceux-ci la mirent dans celle des enchâtres (compartiments) qu'ils voulurent. Les enfants portèrent leurs boîtes au chancelier, qui versa les ballottes des enchâtres blanches dans un bassin, et jeta les autres. On ballotta de même les trois autres concurrents; puis on compta les suffrages. Donato fut élu, et nous sortîmes.

Tout cela fut fait avec une rapidité surprenante, et en moins de temps qu'il n'y en a que je vous en écris; mais c'étoit une vraie comédie que de voir, en sortant, les prosternations de Donato et les baisers de nourrice qu'on lui donnoit. D'honneur, ils sonnoient à se faire entendre au milieu de la place.

documents.content:
It was through a particular favor, extended by our amiable ambassador, the Comte de Froulay, that we found ourselves granted entry into the very heart of the Venetian Republic's power: the Great Council. The opportunity to witness the election of the General of the Galleys, a post of no small consequence, was one I seized with the utmost curiosity.

The Sala del Maggior Consiglio, the hall where this momentous assembly convened, was indeed immense, as descriptions had foretold, and richly adorned. My eyes, accustomed to the grandest salons of Europe, were nonetheless struck by its sheer scale. It stretched before us, a cavernous space, its ceiling heavy with gold leaf and the ambitious frescoes of Veronese, a constant reminder of the Republic's former glories and the divine mandate it claimed. At the far end, dominating the Signoria’s raised platform, Tintoretto’s colossal "Il Paradiso" loomed, its once vibrant colors now mellowed and deepened by centuries, casting a somber, almost severe backdrop behind the empty ducal throne.

Long rows of benches, upholstered in dark fabric, lined the walls, creating wide aisles. As the nobles streamed in, they took their places without any discernible order, a swirling tide of black togas. The heat of August, compounded by the press of so many bodies, made the air thick and heavy. A constant, low hum, like a disturbed hive, filled the vast chamber. Some of the "robes rouges"—those of senatorial rank, I presumed—attempted to impose some semblance of quiet, dispersing themselves strategically, yet their efforts proved utterly futile. The assembly was a veritable pandemonium, a "sabbat de l'autre monde," as I noted to Sainte-Palaye, who stood beside me, equally bewildered by the din. It seemed that in this august body, awaiting the commencement of official proceedings simply meant engaging in a vigorous exchange of whispers, gestures, and covert negotiations. One could almost hear the rustle of political intrigue amidst the shuffling of feet and the incessant murmur of voices. It was less a legislative body and more a bustling marketplace of influence, where men "peloted" – engaged in informal, often playful, exchanges – while awaiting the serious "partie."

Eventually, a semblance of order was restored, or rather, the next stage of the ritual began despite the underlying commotion. Near the Grand Chancellor’s position on the estrade, a large urn was brought forth. This was for the sortition, the drawing of lots that would select a portion of the electors. One by one, the nobles, their faces a mix of anticipation and feigned indifference, approached the urn. A small boy, no older than ten, dressed in a simple tunic, stood beside it, his innocent hand plunged into the depths. He would draw a small ball for each patrician. A gold ball signified the honor of becoming an elector for the charge in question; a silver one, merely the privilege of observing. The tension in the air, though subtle, was palpable as each man awaited his fate. This blend of pure chance with established rank, ensuring that even the most obscure noble had a theoretical path to influence, struck me as a peculiar, yet effective, mechanism to prevent absolute factional control, or at least to provide the illusion of fairness. Many a hopeful gaze followed the Ballottino's hand, only to quickly mask disappointment with a polite nod when a silver ball was revealed.

Once the initial selection by lot was complete, the scene shifted. We were directed to an adjacent chamber, the Sala dello Scrutinio, which, though similarly ornate, was noticeably smaller and filled with fewer benches. This was where the chosen electors, along with those who held the right to vote by virtue of their office, would gather. They entered with a ritualistic gravity that contrasted sharply with the previous hubbub, each bowing deeply to those already seated, a display of deference that bordered on the theatrical.

As the last elector took his place, a hush finally fell over the room. The Grand Chancellor appeared, a figure of sober authority, his presence preceded by a retinue of secretaries, mere functionaries in comparison, yet vital to the machinery of the state. Behind the Chancellor, the Vice-Doge entered, a venerable figure representing the ailing Doge Pisani. It was well-known that the Doge was indisposed, and the eldest of the counselors assumed his duties, though without the ducal *corno* or the right to sit upon the actual throne. He wore his black taffeta *barretta*, its peak pulled forward in a Phrygian style, an imitation of ducal headgear, giving him the appearance of a venerable Antenor. His crimson toga, the mark of his high office, swept behind him as he moved. All rose as he entered, and he returned their salutations with profound bows, only removing his *barretta* for a moment as he passed before the bench of the Quarantia Criminelle, the supreme criminal court, a singular mark of respect. He alone, in that entire assembly, wore his head covering, a subtle assertion of his temporary, yet weighty, authority.

He ascended the estrade and took his seat, surrounded by the *Savi*, the Grandi, and other high officials, while the Chancellor positioned himself at the head of the secretaries on one of the wings. The assembly, though smaller, now possessed an undeniable air of majesty and purpose.

The Chancellor then rose again, his voice carrying clearly through the now quiet hall, and announced the names of the contenders for the post of General of the Galleys: "The most excellent lords Priuli, Badoar, Donato, and Vendramini." Immediately, a number of nobles, those who were close relatives of the candidates, stood and quietly exited the chamber, a procedural safeguard against any familial influence. Following this, the three *Avvogadori di Comun*, those guardians of the Republic's laws, stepped forward. Each held a small Gospel book, which they carried through the rows, inviting every noble to touch it with the tip of their finger. This solemn gesture served as an oath, a sacred promise to proceed with the election in good faith, free from *brigue*—that insidious political maneuvering and bribery that, despite all these elaborate rituals, was never truly absent from Venetian life.

With these lengthy preliminaries concluded, a large usher, whom I mentally dubbed a "marsouin" for his imposing bulk, stepped forward. He adjusted a monstrous pair of spectacles upon a nose that was, if anything, even more monstrous, and in a booming, nasal voice, proclaimed: "Vexcellentissimo signore Luca Priuli!" At once, the chamber was filled with a flurry of activity. Some twenty young boys, dressed in bright red tunics—like those from the public hospitals, I thought, recalling the institutions for orphans—scattered throughout the hall. They cried out, "Priuli! Priuli!" with an almost frantic enthusiasm, their voices echoing like lost souls. Each boy carried a small wooden box, or *bussola*, divided into two compartments: one white, for "yes," and one green, for "no." The common opening, shaped like a funnel, prevented any observer from seeing into which compartment a hand might drop a ball. From small pouches at their belts, filled with tiny linen balls, resembling shirt buttons, they offered one to each noble. The patricians, with practiced ease, chose their compartment, casting their vote in secret. The boys then returned their boxes to the Chancellor, who emptied the white balls into a large basin, discarding the green ones. This process was repeated for each of the other three candidates.

Finally, the counting of the suffrages began. It was done with a speed that defied the intricate nature of the preceding rituals, completed in less time than it takes me now to recount it. The result was swiftly announced: Donato had been elected. As we prepared to depart, the scene transformed into a veritable comedy. Donato, his face beaming, was besieged by well-wishers. There were profound bows, fervent handshakes, and, most memorably, a series of what I could only describe as "nurse's kisses"—loud, resounding smacks on the cheek that, I swear, could be heard reverberating all the way across the Piazzetta. It was a spectacle of effusive congratulations, an outpouring of exaggerated sentiment that perfectly encapsulated the theatricality and underlying machinations of Venetian politics. Despite the solemnity of the occasion and the gravity of the office, it was clear that even in their most important acts of governance, the Venetians never entirely shed their flair for public performance.

Simulation Data Sheet: The Great Council of Venice (1740)


Document Objective

This document serves as a knowledge base for a text-based simulation (LLM). It details the mechanics, atmosphere, and procedures of the Maggior Consiglio (Great Council) in 1740, based on the institutional analysis of Amelot de La Houssaye and historical data regarding the daily life of the Republic.

1. The Space: La Sala del Maggior Consiglio

For the simulation, the space acts as a constraining environment that dictates movement and social interaction.

Architecture and Symbolism

Dimensions: A massive hall (53m x 25m) free of supporting columns, capable of holding between 1,000 and 2,000 patricians.
The Ceiling: Heavy with gold leaf and paintings (notably Veronese’s The Triumph of Venice). It serves as a constant reminder of the divine and state hierarchy.
The East Wall (Il Paradiso): Dominated by Tintoretto’s immense canvas, located above the Signoria's tribune. By 1740, the painting had darkened with time, creating a severe backdrop behind the Doge.
The Tribune (La Signoria): A raised platform where the Doge, his six counselors, and the three chiefs of the Quarantia sit. They physically overlook the assembly.
The Benches (Banchi): Arranged in double rows parallel to the walls, leaving a vast central aisle empty for voting procedures.1

Annexed Spaces (Crucial for Intrigue)

The Liagò: A closed loggia or terrace adjacent to the hall. It is a "decompression" zone where nobles withdraw to speak freely, negotiate votes away from the Signoria’s gaze, or escape the stifling air of the main hall.2
The Sala dello Scrutinio: An adjacent hall often used for counting votes or secondary balloting procedures.3

Sensory Atmosphere

Acoustics: The sheer volume of the hall and the number of participants create a constant background hum (buzzing). Official readings by the Chancellor are often inaudible to those seated at the far ends.
Light and Temperature: The hall is lit by large windows facing the lagoon. In winter, it is notoriously freezing (nobles keep their fur-lined cloaks on). In summer, the heat and the proximity of bodies make the air oppressive.4

2. The Actors: Patrician Sociology (1740)

The simulation must distinguish between three classes of nobles, who are legally equal but economically and politically divided.

The Three Classes

The "Case Vecchie" and the Rich: Historic families or immense new fortunes. They monopolize high executive offices (Savi, Council of Ten, Ambassadors). They use the Great Council to validate their power, though real decisions are made in the Senate.5
The Middle Nobility: They aim for judicial (Quarantie) and administrative offices. They are often legalistic and attached to procedure.
The Barnabotti (The Noble Plebs):
Definition: Impoverished nobles, often living in the parish of San Barnaba. They have lost their fortunes but retain their vote in the Council.6
Role in Simulation: They constitute an electoral maneuver mass. Barred from trade and manual labor, their only "commodity" is their vote. They are known to be unruly and to sell their suffrage in exchange for informal gratuities (protection, loans, meals).7

Costume (Visual Code)

The Vesta (Toga): Mandatory for all. A long black gown with large sleeves (a comito). In winter, it is lined with fur; in summer, it is made of light silk.9
The Stola (Stole): A band of black cloth worn over the left shoulder. Its width and lining indicate rank (ordinary for a simple noble, wide and fur-lined for Senators and Councilors).10
The Wig: By 1740, the use of the powdered wig is generalized, creating an anachronistic contrast between the medieval costume (toga) and the Rococo hairstyle. High, voluminous wigs are a sign of fashion and wealth.

3. The Political Ritual


Before the Session: The Broglio

Location: The Piazzetta San Marco, before the bell rings.
Action: This is the time for electoral solicitation. Candidates ("solicitors") stand on one side, electors on the other.12
Gestures: Open campaigning is forbidden by law. Everything occurs through codes of exaggerated politeness: deep bows, kissing of the sleeve or stole, and whispered requests for support ("Mi raccomando").12
The Trottiera: The specific bell that announces the imminent start of the session, urging latecomers to hasten to the palace.4

During the Session: Voting and Chance

The Venetian system, detailed by Amelot de La Houssaye, relies on a complex mix of Sortition (to prevent factions) and Election (to ensure competence).

The Tools

The Ballottino: A boy aged 8 to 10, often dressed in white, tasked with drawing balls from the urns to guarantee the innocence of chance.3
The Bussole (Urns): Wooden structures allowing for secret voting. The noble inserts his hand and drops his ball into a hidden tube (the "Yes" tube or "No" tube).
The Balls (Balote): Small balls made of compressed linen (for silence).
Gold: Winning ball (for sortition).
Silver: Losing ball.
White / Red (or Green): Used for voting "Yes" or "No" during legislative or judicial scrutinies.3

The "Four Hands" Procedure (Election of Magistrates)

This is the standard procedure for electing state officials.14
The Sortition: Each noble passes before an urn. The Ballottino draws a ball for him. If he gets a Gold ball, he becomes an Elector. This continues until 36 electors are chosen.14
The Division: The 36 electors are isolated and divided into 4 groups of 9, called "Hands" (Mani).
The Nomination (Secret): Each "Hand," isolated in a separate room, must agree (by a majority of 6 out of 9) to propose one candidate for the vacant post.
The General Ballot: The 4 names proposed (one by each "Hand") are announced to the Great Council. The entire assembly then votes for or against each candidate. The one with the most votes wins.14

4. Simulation Data Cards


Card A: Sequence of Actions (Sunday Routine)

10:00 AM - Broglio: Social interaction on the Piazza. Informal negotiations.
10:30 AM - Trottiera: Sound signal. Crowd movement towards the Giants' Staircase.
11:00 AM - Installation: Entry into the hall. Barnabotti seek strategic seats or cluster together.
11:30 AM - Reading: The Chancellor reads the list of vacant posts. Ambient hubbub.
12:00 PM - Lottery (Ballottino): Slow procession before the urn. Tension of the Gold/Silver draw.
1:00 PM - Conclave of the 4 Hands: Session suspension for the 36 electors. Others wait, chat in the Liagò.
2:00 PM - Final Vote: Procession to the Bussole to validate candidates.

Card B: Tension Variables

These modifiers can be used to generate incidents or intrigues in the simulation.
Cold/Heat: Impatience factor. Can push nobles to rush a vote or leave the session early (if the quorum is not threatened).
Vote Selling: A player may be approached by an agent of a rich family: "A dinner invitation in exchange for a white ball for candidate Cornaro."6
Procedural Error: If the Ballottino makes a mistake or an urn is improperly closed, the Quarantie (judges) must intervene, creating a dramatic interruption.

Le premier ouvrier, qui tient la verge à laquelle est
attaché ce globe , le tourne fort vite tandis que le
second lâche peu à peu la main qui tient les ciseaux.
De cette manière l'ovale s'ouvre en entier par l'un
des bouts, comme un marli de verre. Alors on le dé-
tache de la première verge de fer , et on le scelle de
nouveau, par le bout ouvert, à une autre verge faite
exprès ; puis on l'ouvre par l'autre bout avec le
même mécanisme que celui décrit ci-dessus. Tl en
résulte un long cylindre de glace d'un large dia-
mètre, qu'on représente, en le tournant, à la bouche
du fourneau pour Tamollir un peu de nouveau ; et ,
au sortir de là, tout en un clin d'œil, d'un seul coup
de ciseau, l'on coupe la glace en long , et prompte-
ment on l'étend tout à plat sur une table de cuivre.
Il ne faut plus après que la recuire davantage dans

222 XIX. —A M. DE MALETESTE.
un autre four, puis la polir et Fétamer à l'ordinaire.
A propos, ne vous avisez pas, à mon retour, de me
donner moins de Vexcellence. J'en ai contracté la
douce habitude ; pour de l'illustrissime , je ne m'en
soucie plus : il est ici à rien.
Nous serons demain de retour à Padoue, d'où nous
partirons en poste pour Bologne et Florence. De là
par le détour de Lucques , Pise et Livourne , nous
nous rendrons à Rome ; c'est là que je compte trou-
ver de vos nouvelles à l'adresse du directeur de la
poste de France.
P. S. J'ai reçu votre lettre mon charmant Neuilly,
et vous pouvez juger du plaisir qu'elle m'a fait, ve-
nant d'un ami tel que vous. Je tacherai de vous en
faire raison sur la route, aussi bien que de toutes les
extravagances qui sont dans celle-ci. Mais vous êtes
un ami commode ; votre vertu n'est sévère que pour
vous. Adieu, mes princes, mille et mille choses à nos
amis et amies. On vous embrasse ici.

[HOW TO USE]: Here is the event text that must be augmented. It comes from Charles de Brosses's "Lettres familières d'Italie". Please bridge the gaps between the events that de Brosses describes in a plausible way.
On nous fit la faveur de nous faire entrer au Grand Conseil pour voir l'élection du général des galères, charge assez importante. Le Grand Conseil se tient dans une salle immense et bien ornée. Dans le fond est une estrade où sont les places des conseillers et des inquisiteurs d'État, avec le trône du doge au milieu. L'estrade surbaissée tourne tout autour de la salle, et de longs rangs de bancs adossés les uns aux autres et rangés en allées remplissent la salle. Tous les nobles entrèrent là sans ordre et se placèrent. Les robes rouges avoient leurs places marquées, et quelques-unes se dispersèrent en différents lieux de la salle, pour empêcher qu'il ne se fît du bruit dans une si nombreuse assemblée; chose, à mon gré, où ils ne réussirent nullement, puisque l'on y faisoit un sabbat de l'autre monde; aussi ne faisoit-on là que peloter en attendant partie.

Près du grand chancelier, sur l'estrade, il y avoit une urne contenant autant de petites boules qu'il y avoit de personnes, et parmi ces boules un certain nombre de dorées ; chacun tira la sienne. Ceux à qui échurent celles dorées furent les électeurs de la charge en question, avec une grande quantité d'autres qui, par leurs places, étoient électeurs de droit.

Cela fait, nous passâmes dans la salle du scrutin, ornée de la même manière que la première, moins grande, remplie de bancs, l'assemblée y étant moins nombreuse. Les autres électeurs entrèrent l'un après l'autre, saluant jusqu'à terre les précédents, avec une gravité sans pareille. Dès qu'ils eurent tous défilé, le chancelier parut, précédé du corps des secrétaires, gens subalternes, et précédant lui-même le vice-doge; car le doge étoit malade, et c'est le plus vieux des conseillers qui le représente. Mais il ne s'assied pas sur le trône et n'a pas le corno; il l'imitoit tant qu'il pouvoit, ayant mis sur sa tête sa barrette ou bonnet de taffetas noir, dont il ramenoit le sommet par devant en bec à la phrygienne, comme un véritable Anténor. Il étoit suivi de tous les conseillers en robes rouges. Dès qu'il parut, toute l'assemblée se leva; il la salua profondément, sans ôter sa barrette que pour la Quarantie criminelle, lorsqu'il passa devant elle. Seul, de toute l'assemblée, il l'avoit sur la tête.

Il monta sur l'estrade et s'assit. Les sages, grands et autres, se placèrent autour de lui, et sur les ailes le chancelier, à la tête des secrétaires, dont il est le chef. Cette assemblée avoit l'air tout à fait majestueux.

Alors le chancelier se leva et dit que les seigneurs Priuli, Badoar, Donato et Vendramini demandoient la charge en question. Sur-le-champ leurs parents proches se levèrent et sortirent. Immédiatement après, les trois avvogadori prirent chacun un petit évangile, et parcoururent les rangs en faisant toucher à chacun cet évangile du bout du doigt, marque du serment de procéder à l'élection de bonne foi et sans brigue.

Tous ces préalables finis, un grand marsouin d'huissier, ayant mis une paire de lunettes monstrueuses sur un nez qui l'étoit davantage, proclama d'un ton nasillard : « Vexcellentissimo signore Luca Priuli. » À l'instant, une vingtaine de petits enfants rouges, comme ceux de l'hôpital, se dispersèrent par la salle, criant comme des perdus : « Priuli ! Priuli ! » Ils avoient chacun à la main une boîte à deux compartiments, l'un blanc pour nommer, l'autre vert pour refuser; l'ouverture commune étant faite en entonnoir, afin que les assistants ne puissent voir dans laquelle des deux divisions on met la main, et à la ceinture une gibecière pleine de petites ballottes comme des boutons de chemisette; ils en donnèrent une à chaque noble. Ceux-ci la mirent dans celle des enchâtres (compartiments) qu'ils voulurent. Les enfants portèrent leurs boîtes au chancelier, qui versa les ballottes des enchâtres blanches dans un bassin, et jeta les autres. On ballotta de même les trois autres concurrents; puis on compta les suffrages. Donato fut élu, et nous sortîmes.

Tout cela fut fait avec une rapidité surprenante, et en moins de temps qu'il n'y en a que je vous en écris; mais c'étoit une vraie comédie que de voir, en sortant, les prosternations de Donato et les baisers de nourrice qu'on lui donnoit. D'honneur, ils sonnoient à se faire entendre au milieu de la place.

documents.content:
It was through the good offices of the Comte de Froulay, our esteemed ambassador, that this singular privilege was arranged. He had, as I have observed, taken great pains to ensure our comfort and access in Venice, and this invitation to witness the election of the *Generale delle Galere* was certainly among the most remarkable. The charge, as I understood, was one of considerable importance, overseeing the Republic's naval forces, a vital post for a maritime power.

We arrived at the Doge's Palace in the late morning, a time when the Piazzetta San Marco was already a bustling theatre of life, yet distinct from the frantic *broglio* that precedes the Great Council sessions. The *trottiera* had already sounded, and the last stragglers, their black *veste* fluttering, hurried towards the Giants' Staircase. Our entry was discreet, guided by one of the Ambassador's secretaries, a sharp-eyed young man who seemed to navigate the palace's labyrinthine passages with innate ease.

The Sala del Maggior Consiglio, when we finally entered, was indeed immense and richly adorned, precisely as described in the pamphlets. My gaze was immediately drawn to the ceiling, a vast expanse heavy with gold leaf and the vibrant, if somewhat faded, triumphs painted by Veronese. It conveyed an overwhelming sense of the Republic's enduring grandeur, a silent sermon on divine and state hierarchy. Directly ahead, above the raised platform of the Signoria, Tintoretto’s colossal *Il Paradiso* loomed, its dark, monumental forms creating a severe backdrop that seemed to absorb the light rather than reflect it. The hall itself, free of supporting columns, stretched for an astonishing length, capable, I was told, of accommodating upwards of a thousand patricians. Today, it was filled to near capacity.

Long rows of benches, arranged parallel to the walls, created wide aisles. The atmosphere was a peculiar blend of grandeur and cacophony. A constant hum, a veritable "sabbat de l'autre monde" as I noted, filled the cavernous space. Patricians, clad in their mandated black *veste*—some with fur linings against the persistent chill of the stone, others of lighter silk—milled about or settled into their seats without apparent order. Their powdered wigs, often towering and voluminous, struck an anachronistic contrast with the medieval cut of their robes. The *stola*, a black band over the left shoulder, varied in width and lining, subtly denoting rank, though all were ostensibly equal in this assembly.

I observed the *Case Vecchie* and the immensely rich, identifiable by their confident bearing and the clusters of lesser nobles gravitating towards them. They held court in hushed tones, their faces betraying little, yet their gestures hinted at ongoing negotiations. Further back, the middle nobility, with their more earnest, legalistic air, discussed procedures, while the *Barnabotti*, those impoverished nobles from the parish of San Barnaba, huddled together. Their votes, their sole remaining commodity, were undoubtedly being solicited, perhaps with promises of a good meal or a small loan, a common practice in this Republic where even the highest offices were subject to such informal brigandage. The Doge's throne, centrally placed on the elevated *Signoria* platform, stood empty, a silent testament to his current indisposition. The six counselors and the three chiefs of the Quarantia occupied the seats around it, their red robes standing out against the black sea of the assembly. They seemed to physically overlook the whole, yet the general hubbub below suggested their gaze was not always keenly felt. It was, as I thought, a strange theatre of power, where such solemnity could co-exist with so much undirected energy.

The initial proceedings began with the Chancellor, a figure of quiet authority, rising from his place on the estrade. His voice, though amplified by the hall's acoustics, struggled to cut through the sustained buzz. He read, with a certain drone, the list of vacant posts, among which was the *Generale delle Galere*. Few seemed to listen with rapt attention, their "peloting" conversations continuing, a low murmur of political chess.

Then came the first formal step: the sortition. Near the Chancellor, on the estrade, stood a wooden urn. The process was a fascinating blend of chance and design, intended, I gathered, to prevent outright factionalism. A small boy, perhaps eight or ten years of age, dressed in a simple white tunic, stood beside the urn. This was the *Ballottino*, whose innocence was meant to guarantee the impartiality of fate. Each noble, in turn, began to file past the urn. There was a slight quickening of the pace, a ripple of anticipation. As each man approached, the *Ballottino* would dip his small hand into the urn and draw forth a single ball. Some were gold, others silver. Those who received a gold ball were designated as electors for the charge in question. This continued, a slow, deliberate procession, until thirty-six electors had been chosen by this lottery. Alongside these men of chance, a "grande quantité d'autres," those who held specific offices, were electors by right of their position, their status already guaranteeing their participation. The tension in the air was palpable, particularly among the *Barnabotti*, for whom the opportunity to be an elector, even by chance, could open doors to influence, or at least, a temporary improvement in their fortunes. I watched one such noble, his black *veste* a little threadbare, his wig slightly askew, draw a gold ball. A faint, almost imperceptible smile touched his lips, quickly suppressed into an expression of customary gravity. The drawing completed, the main body of the Great Council was effectively suspended, their role for this stage of the election concluded.

Following the sortition, we—my companions and I—were ushered into an adjacent chamber, the Sala dello Scrutinio. It was also adorned with paintings and rich tapestries, though noticeably smaller than the main hall. Here, the assembly was indeed less numerous, comprising only the newly selected electors and those of right. The atmosphere, too, had shifted. The earlier "sabbat" had given way to a more solemn, focused air.

The chosen electors, thirty-six in number, had, I presumed, already been isolated and divided into four groups, or "Hands," each tasked with secretly proposing a candidate. Now, they entered the Sala dello Scrutinio, one after another, their demeanour markedly grave. Each noble performed a profound bow, a respectful salutation "jusqu'à terre," before those already assembled, an act of ritualized deference that underscored the seriousness of their task. The silence, broken only by the rustle of robes and the creak of the old floorboards, was a stark contrast to the buzzing of the Great Council.

Once all the electors had taken their places, a new procession entered. First came the Chancellor, a man of imposing presence, his dark *veste* and wide, fur-lined *stola* denoting his high office. He was preceded by a body of secretaries, younger men in simpler black robes, their faces earnest. Following the Chancellor, with even greater ceremony, came the Vice-Doge. The true Doge, as we knew, was ailing, and so the oldest of the six councillors had assumed his representative duties. He did not, however, sit upon the ornate throne in the main hall, nor did he wear the distinctive *corno*, the ducal cap. Instead, he wore a simple black taffeta *barretta*, or bonnet, its peak pulled forward "en bec à la phrygienne," giving him the appearance, as I thought, of an ancient Antenor, a dignified if slightly anachronistic figure. He was followed by the remaining councillors, their red robes providing a splash of colour against the prevailing black.

As the Vice-Doge appeared, the entire assembly rose, a wave of black and red. He returned their salutation with a deep bow, his *barretta* remaining firmly on his head, save for a moment of specific deference. As he passed before the *Quarantia Criminelle*, the Republic's highest criminal court, he briefly removed his cap, a singular gesture of respect shown to no other body in the assembly. It was a subtle, yet potent, display of the intricate hierarchies within the Republic. He then ascended the estrade and took his seat, flanked by the "sages, grands et autres" — the highest magistrates and officials — while the Chancellor, at the head of his secretaries, positioned himself on the wings. This arrangement, formal and precise, lent the assembly an air of undeniable majesty.

The Chancellor rose again, his voice now clear and resonant. He announced the names of the four candidates proposed by the various "Hands": "Les seigneurs Priuli, Badoar, Donato et Vendramini demandoient la charge en question." A ripple went through the assembly as these names, all from ancient and powerful families, were spoken. Immediately, as per custom, any close relatives of the four candidates rose from their places and exited the hall. This was a measure, I understood, to prevent any undue influence or appearance of impropriety, though the efficacy of such a gesture, given the pervasive nature of Venetian political maneuvering, was a matter for private cynicism.

No sooner had the relatives departed than three *Avvogadori de Comun* stepped forward. These were the Republic's public prosecutors, the guardians of its laws, and their presence underscored the solemnity of the moment. Each held a small Gospel book. With grave faces, they moved through the ranks of the electors, extending the book to each noble. Every man, in turn, touched the Gospel with the tip of his finger, a silent, symbolic oath to proceed with the election in good faith, without *brigue* or corruption. I observed this ritual with a certain detached amusement. The earnestness of the gesture stood in stark contrast to the constant undercurrent of intrigue and vote-selling I had heard so much about in Venice. One could not help but wonder how many of these solemn vows would survive the passage of the balloting box.

With these formalities concluded, the final act of the election commenced. A massive usher, whom I privately dubbed a "grand marsouin" for his ponderous bulk, stepped forward. His nose, already formidable, was further exaggerated by a pair of "lunettes monstrueuses" perched upon it. He cleared his throat and, in a nasal, booming voice, proclaimed: "Vexcellentissimo signore Luca Priuli!"

At this signal, a veritable explosion of youthful energy erupted. Some twenty small boys, dressed in bright red tunics—much like those from the *ospedali* I had heard about, where orphans were trained in music—scattered throughout the hall. They cried out, "Priuli! Priuli!" with an almost frantic enthusiasm, their high-pitched voices echoing through the chamber. Each child carried a small wooden box, a *bussola*, divided into two compartments: one white for "yes" (or "nommer"), the other green for "no" (or "refuser"). The common opening was funnel-shaped, cleverly designed to prevent anyone from seeing into which compartment a noble placed his hand. From a pouch at their belt, a *gibecière* filled with small, linen balls "comme des boutons de chemisette," they offered one to each noble.

The electors, one by one, took a ball and, with a practiced hand, deposited it into the desired compartment of the *bussola*. The linen balls, I knew, were used specifically for their silence, ensuring the secrecy of the vote. The red-clad children, having collected the ballots, then hurried back to the Chancellor. He, in turn, carefully emptied the balls from the white compartments into a large silver basin, while discarding those from the green. This process was then repeated for each of the other three candidates: Badoar, Vendramini, and finally, Donato. The cries of the children changed with each name, "Donato! Donato!" resounding through the hall.

The counting of the suffrages followed swiftly. I was struck by the efficiency with which the entire procedure was conducted. Despite the elaborate ritual and the multitude of participants, the election seemed to conclude with surprising rapidity, certainly in less time than it took me to commit these observations to paper. Finally, the Chancellor announced the result: Donato had been elected.

And with that, our unique access concluded. We were ushered out of the Sala dello Scrutinio, and as we emerged, the scene instantly transformed into what I could only describe as a "vraie comédie." Donato, the newly elected *Generale delle Galere*, was immediately besieged by a throng of well-wishers. Nobles, his erstwhile rivals and supporters alike, rushed forward, offering exaggerated "prosternations" and loud, effusive "baisers de nourrice." The sounds of these fervent congratulations, these resounding kisses on cheeks and shoulders, were so hearty, so theatrical, that they echoed through the corridors and, I swear, could be heard even amidst the general clamour of the Piazzetta San Marco. It was a vivid display of Venetian political theatre, a blend of sincere joy, performative loyalty, and perhaps, a touch of relief that the day's machinations had finally yielded a result. It was, I reflected, a fitting end to a day spent observing the intricate, often absurd, yet undeniably captivating mechanics of the Venetian Republic.

Simulation Data Sheet: The Great Council of Venice (1740)


Document Objective

This document serves as a knowledge base for a text-based simulation (LLM). It details the mechanics, atmosphere, and procedures of the Maggior Consiglio (Great Council) in 1740, based on the institutional analysis of Amelot de La Houssaye and historical data regarding the daily life of the Republic.

1. The Space: La Sala del Maggior Consiglio

For the simulation, the space acts as a constraining environment that dictates movement and social interaction.

Architecture and Symbolism

Dimensions: A massive hall (53m x 25m) free of supporting columns, capable of holding between 1,000 and 2,000 patricians.
The Ceiling: Heavy with gold leaf and paintings (notably Veronese’s The Triumph of Venice). It serves as a constant reminder of the divine and state hierarchy.
The East Wall (Il Paradiso): Dominated by Tintoretto’s immense canvas, located above the Signoria's tribune. By 1740, the painting had darkened with time, creating a severe backdrop behind the Doge.
The Tribune (La Signoria): A raised platform where the Doge, his six counselors, and the three chiefs of the Quarantia sit. They physically overlook the assembly.
The Benches (Banchi): Arranged in double rows parallel to the walls, leaving a vast central aisle empty for voting procedures.1

Annexed Spaces (Crucial for Intrigue)

The Liagò: A closed loggia or terrace adjacent to the hall. It is a "decompression" zone where nobles withdraw to speak freely, negotiate votes away from the Signoria’s gaze, or escape the stifling air of the main hall.2
The Sala dello Scrutinio: An adjacent hall often used for counting votes or secondary balloting procedures.3

Sensory Atmosphere

Acoustics: The sheer volume of the hall and the number of participants create a constant background hum (buzzing). Official readings by the Chancellor are often inaudible to those seated at the far ends.
Light and Temperature: The hall is lit by large windows facing the lagoon. In winter, it is notoriously freezing (nobles keep their fur-lined cloaks on). In summer, the heat and the proximity of bodies make the air oppressive.4

2. The Actors: Patrician Sociology (1740)

The simulation must distinguish between three classes of nobles, who are legally equal but economically and politically divided.

The Three Classes

The "Case Vecchie" and the Rich: Historic families or immense new fortunes. They monopolize high executive offices (Savi, Council of Ten, Ambassadors). They use the Great Council to validate their power, though real decisions are made in the Senate.5
The Middle Nobility: They aim for judicial (Quarantie) and administrative offices. They are often legalistic and attached to procedure.
The Barnabotti (The Noble Plebs):
Definition: Impoverished nobles, often living in the parish of San Barnaba. They have lost their fortunes but retain their vote in the Council.6
Role in Simulation: They constitute an electoral maneuver mass. Barred from trade and manual labor, their only "commodity" is their vote. They are known to be unruly and to sell their suffrage in exchange for informal gratuities (protection, loans, meals).7

Costume (Visual Code)

The Vesta (Toga): Mandatory for all. A long black gown with large sleeves (a comito). In winter, it is lined with fur; in summer, it is made of light silk.9
The Stola (Stole): A band of black cloth worn over the left shoulder. Its width and lining indicate rank (ordinary for a simple noble, wide and fur-lined for Senators and Councilors).10
The Wig: By 1740, the use of the powdered wig is generalized, creating an anachronistic contrast between the medieval costume (toga) and the Rococo hairstyle. High, voluminous wigs are a sign of fashion and wealth.

3. The Political Ritual


Before the Session: The Broglio

Location: The Piazzetta San Marco, before the bell rings.
Action: This is the time for electoral solicitation. Candidates ("solicitors") stand on one side, electors on the other.12
Gestures: Open campaigning is forbidden by law. Everything occurs through codes of exaggerated politeness: deep bows, kissing of the sleeve or stole, and whispered requests for support ("Mi raccomando").12
The Trottiera: The specific bell that announces the imminent start of the session, urging latecomers to hasten to the palace.4

During the Session: Voting and Chance

The Venetian system, detailed by Amelot de La Houssaye, relies on a complex mix of Sortition (to prevent factions) and Election (to ensure competence).

The Tools

The Ballottino: A boy aged 8 to 10, often dressed in white, tasked with drawing balls from the urns to guarantee the innocence of chance.3
The Bussole (Urns): Wooden structures allowing for secret voting. The noble inserts his hand and drops his ball into a hidden tube (the "Yes" tube or "No" tube).
The Balls (Balote): Small balls made of compressed linen (for silence).
Gold: Winning ball (for sortition).
Silver: Losing ball.
White / Red (or Green): Used for voting "Yes" or "No" during legislative or judicial scrutinies.3

The "Four Hands" Procedure (Election of Magistrates)

This is the standard procedure for electing state officials.14
The Sortition: Each noble passes before an urn. The Ballottino draws a ball for him. If he gets a Gold ball, he becomes an Elector. This continues until 36 electors are chosen.14
The Division: The 36 electors are isolated and divided into 4 groups of 9, called "Hands" (Mani).
The Nomination (Secret): Each "Hand," isolated in a separate room, must agree (by a majority of 6 out of 9) to propose one candidate for the vacant post.
The General Ballot: The 4 names proposed (one by each "Hand") are announced to the Great Council. The entire assembly then votes for or against each candidate. The one with the most votes wins.14

4. Simulation Data Cards


Card A: Sequence of Actions (Sunday Routine)

10:00 AM - Broglio: Social interaction on the Piazza. Informal negotiations.
10:30 AM - Trottiera: Sound signal. Crowd movement towards the Giants' Staircase.
11:00 AM - Installation: Entry into the hall. Barnabotti seek strategic seats or cluster together.
11:30 AM - Reading: The Chancellor reads the list of vacant posts. Ambient hubbub.
12:00 PM - Lottery (Ballottino): Slow procession before the urn. Tension of the Gold/Silver draw.
1:00 PM - Conclave of the 4 Hands: Session suspension for the 36 electors. Others wait, chat in the Liagò.
2:00 PM - Final Vote: Procession to the Bussole to validate candidates.

Card B: Tension Variables

These modifiers can be used to generate incidents or intrigues in the simulation.
Cold/Heat: Impatience factor. Can push nobles to rush a vote or leave the session early (if the quorum is not threatened).
Vote Selling: A player may be approached by an agent of a rich family: "A dinner invitation in exchange for a white ball for candidate Cornaro."6
Procedural Error: If the Ballottino makes a mistake or an urn is improperly closed, the Quarantie (judges) must intervene, creating a dramatic interruption.

On nous fit la faveur de nous faire entrer au Grand Conseil pour voir l'élection du général des galères, charge assez importante. Le Grand Conseil se tient dans une salle immense et bien ornée. Dans le fond est une estrade où sont les places des conseillers et des inquisiteurs d'État, avec le trône du doge au milieu. L'estrade surbaissée tourne tout autour de la salle, et de longs rangs de bancs adossés les uns aux autres et rangés en allées remplissent la salle. Tous les nobles entrèrent là sans ordre et se placèrent. Les robes rouges avoient leurs places marquées, et quelques-unes se dispersèrent en différents lieux de la salle, pour empêcher qu'il ne se fît du bruit dans une si nombreuse assemblée; chose, à mon gré, où ils ne réussirent nullement, puisque l'on y faisoit un sabbat de l'autre monde; aussi ne faisoit-on là que peloter en attendant partie.

Près du grand chancelier, sur l'estrade, il y avoit une urne contenant autant de petites boules qu'il y avoit de personnes, et parmi ces boules un certain nombre de dorées ; chacun tira la sienne. Ceux à qui échurent celles dorées furent les électeurs de la charge en question, avec une grande quantité d'autres qui, par leurs places, étoient électeurs de droit.

Cela fait, nous passâmes dans la salle du scrutin, ornée de la même manière que la première, moins grande, remplie de bancs, l'assemblée y étant moins nombreuse. Les autres électeurs entrèrent l'un après l'autre, saluant jusqu'à terre les précédents, avec une gravité sans pareille. Dès qu'ils eurent tous défilé, le chancelier parut, précédé du corps des secrétaires, gens subalternes, et précédant lui-même le vice-doge; car le doge étoit malade, et c'est le plus vieux des conseillers qui le représente. Mais il ne s'assied pas sur le trône et n'a pas le corno; il l'imitoit tant qu'il pouvoit, ayant mis sur sa tête sa barrette ou bonnet de taffetas noir, dont il ramenoit le sommet par devant en bec à la phrygienne, comme un véritable Anténor. Il étoit suivi de tous les conseillers en robes rouges. Dès qu'il parut, toute l'assemblée se leva; il la salua profondément, sans ôter sa barrette que pour la Quarantie criminelle, lorsqu'il passa devant elle. Seul, de toute l'assemblée, il l'avoit sur la tête.

Il monta sur l'estrade et s'assit. Les sages, grands et autres, se placèrent autour de lui, et sur les ailes le chancelier, à la tête des secrétaires, dont il est le chef. Cette assemblée avoit l'air tout à fait majestueux.

Alors le chancelier se leva et dit que les seigneurs Priuli, Badoar, Donato et Vendramini demandoient la charge en question. Sur-le-champ leurs parents proches se levèrent et sortirent. Immédiatement après, les trois avvogadori prirent chacun un petit évangile, et parcoururent les rangs en faisant toucher à chacun cet évangile du bout du doigt, marque du serment de procéder à l'élection de bonne foi et sans brigue.

Tous ces préalables finis, un grand marsouin d'huissier, ayant mis une paire de lunettes monstrueuses sur un nez qui l'étoit davantage, proclama d'un ton nasillard : « Vexcellentissimo signore Luca Priuli. » À l'instant, une vingtaine de petits enfants rouges, comme ceux de l'hôpital, se dispersèrent par la salle, criant comme des perdus : « Priuli ! Priuli ! » Ils avoient chacun à la main une boîte à deux compartiments, l'un blanc pour nommer, l'autre vert pour refuser; l'ouverture commune étant faite en entonnoir, afin que les assistants ne puissent voir dans laquelle des deux divisions on met la main, et à la ceinture une gibecière pleine de petites ballottes comme des boutons de chemisette; ils en donnèrent une à chaque noble. Ceux-ci la mirent dans celle des enchâtres (compartiments) qu'ils voulurent. Les enfants portèrent leurs boîtes au chancelier, qui versa les ballottes des enchâtres blanches dans un bassin, et jeta les autres. On ballotta de même les trois autres concurrents; puis on compta les suffrages. Donato fut élu, et nous sortîmes.

Tout cela fut fait avec une rapidité surprenante, et en moins de temps qu'il n'y en a que je vous en écris; mais c'étoit une vraie comédie que de voir, en sortant, les prosternations de Donato et les baisers de nourrice qu'on lui donnoit. D'honneur, ils sonnoient à se faire entendre au milieu de la place.

documents.content:
My dear Blancey,

You would scarcely believe the spectacle of Venetian governance, a peculiar blend of ancient ritual and bustling, almost theatrical, disorder. I confess, after the labyrinthine intrigues I recounted regarding Monsieur Tiepolo and Aimo, I possessed a keen desire to witness the mechanisms of this Republic firsthand. It was through the good offices of our ambassador, the Comte de Froulay, who, as you know, so admirably restores our nation’s honour here, that the favour was granted. One crisp morning, not long after my arrival, we found ourselves making our way across the Piazzetta, which, despite its magnificent architecture, always seems to me more a bustling marketplace than a seat of power. The Doge’s Palace, a mass of Gothic severity, loomed before us, its grand staircase, which they call the Giants’ Staircase, already swarming with cloaked figures.

The bell, the *Trottiera* as they name it, had already rung, a frantic clangour urging the tardy nobles into the palace. We ascended the grand marble stairs, a marvel in white and violet, and were led through various richly painted antechambers, where the murmur of voices grew steadily louder. Finally, we were ushered into the Sala del Maggior Consiglio itself, a hall of truly immense proportions, far grander than any I had imagined. Its ceiling, heavy with gold leaf and vast canvases, shimmered above us, depicting triumphs and allegories that seemed to mock the earthly chaos below. Tintoretto’s immense *Il Paradiso* dominated the far wall, a dark and imposing backdrop behind the raised platform where the Doge, or in this case, his representative, would sit.

The hall was indeed filled with row upon row of benches, where patricians, clad in their mandated black togas, were already settling. Yet, to say they "settled" implies a calm which was entirely absent. It was, as I later described, a veritable pandemonium, a "sabbat de l'autre monde." Nobles, from the ancient, wealthy families to the impoverished *Barnabotti* (whose votes, I hear, are as negotiable as a courtesan’s favours), mingled with a loud, unrestrained energy. The men of the "red robes" – the Senators and Councilors – attempted to maintain some semblance of order, dispersing themselves throughout the throng, but their efforts were, to my mind, entirely in vain. The sheer volume of chatter, the rustle of heavy silk and fur-lined cloaks (for even in August, a certain chill seemed to cling to these ancient stones), created a deafening hum. I observed groups huddled together, their powdered wigs bobbing as they whispered, no doubt engaging in the very "brigues" and "ballottages" that Misson so thoroughly documented, and which the Tiepolo-Aimo affair had so vividly illustrated. It was clear that the real politicking, the "pelotage" as I called it, was far from over, even within these hallowed walls. Men would slip away to the adjacent *Liagò*, a loggia, to speak more freely, their animated gestures visible even from our vantage point, before returning to the main hall, their allegiances perhaps subtly shifted.

Our purpose, we were informed, was to witness the election of the *Général des Galères*, a post of no small importance, commanding the Republic’s naval forces. The first step was the sortition, a peculiar Venetian custom meant, so they claim, to thwart factions. Near the Grand Chancellor’s seat on the main estrade, a large wooden urn stood, its polished surface reflecting the faint light from the lagoon-facing windows. From this urn, each noble present was to draw a small ball. I watched as the patricians, one by one, approached, their faces a mix of anticipation, feigned indifference, or genuine anxiety. A young boy, no older than ten, dressed in a simple white tunic, stood beside the urn, his small hand reaching in to present each noble with his fate. These, I learned, were the *Ballottini*, chosen for their innocence to ensure the impartiality of chance. Most balls were silver, signifying a mere spectator’s role, but a select few were gilded. Those fortunate enough to draw a golden ball were to become electors for the charge, joining a larger body of those who held the right to vote by virtue of their existing office. The procession was slow, marked by the rhythmic scrape of feet and the rustle of robes, punctuated by quiet exclamations or sighs as each man’s lot was revealed.

Once the drawing was complete and the appointed electors identified, the assembly began to shift. We were then directed to another, smaller chamber, the Sala dello Scrutinio, which, though similarly adorned with paintings and benches, felt less overwhelming, the crowd noticeably thinner. This was where the decisive act would take place. The newly selected electors, alongside those already designated by their rank, filed in, their entry marked by an almost exaggerated solemnity. Each man, in his turn, performed a profound bow, a theatrical sweep of his arm that brought his powdered wig almost to the ground, before taking his place on the benches. It was a gravity, I must admit, that stood in stark contrast to the earlier cacophony.

Suddenly, a hush fell over the room. The Grand Chancellor appeared, a figure of some authority, preceded by a corps of his secretaries – men of lesser rank, certainly, but indispensable to the Republic’s intricate bureaucracy. Behind him walked the Vice-Doge, the eldest of the Councilors, representing the ailing Doge Pisani. I had heard of the Doge’s ill health, and indeed, I later saw him taking the air, looking frail despite his youthful wig. This Vice-Doge, however, though he could not sit upon the Doge’s gilded throne nor wear the distinctive *corno*, did his utmost to imitate the ducal bearing. He wore a simple black taffeta cap, or *barrette*, pulled forward into a Phrygian point, giving him, as I noted, the air of a veritable Antenor. His retinue of red-robed Councilors followed, their faces set in grave expressions. As he entered, the entire assembly rose, a wave of black and red. The Vice-Doge acknowledged them with a deep bow, his *barrette* remaining firmly on his head, except for a brief, almost imperceptible dip of respect as he passed before the *Quarantia Criminale*, the judicial body whose authority even he acknowledged. He was the only one in the room to keep his head covered throughout.

He ascended the estrade and took his seat, surrounded by the *Sages*, the *Grands*, and other high officials. The Chancellor, at the head of his secretaries, positioned himself on the wings. The assembly, thus arranged, presented a truly majestic appearance, a tableau of Venetian power and tradition. The air was thick with expectation.

Then, the Chancellor rose once more, his voice cutting clearly through the renewed murmur. He announced the names of the four noblemen vying for the prestigious charge: the illustrious Signori Priuli, Badoar, Donato, and Vendramini. Immediately, as custom dictated, any close relatives of these candidates rose from their seats and quietly exited the hall, a gesture meant to prevent any appearance of undue influence or favouritism. Following this, the three *Avvogadori* – state attorneys, guardians of the Republic’s legal integrity – stepped forward. Each held a small Gospel, bound in leather and worn smooth by countless similar ceremonies. They moved through the rows of electors, making each man touch the holy book with the tip of his finger, a solemn oath to proceed with the election in good faith, free from "brigue" or corruption. It was a powerful, if perhaps ironic, gesture, given the pervasive nature of political maneuvering.

With these elaborate preliminaries concluded, a towering usher, whom I could only describe as a "grand marsouin" (a porpoise, for his immense bulk), stepped forward. He wore a monstrous pair of spectacles perched precariously on an even more monstrous nose, and with a nasally, booming voice, he proclaimed: "Vexcellentissimo Signore Luca Priuli!" The announcement was met with an immediate, almost jarring, burst of activity. From the antechamber, a score of small boys, perhaps twenty of them, darted into the hall. They were dressed in crimson tunics, reminiscent of the uniforms worn by the orphans in the *ospedali* – a detail that struck me as curious, given the usual white of the *ballottini*. These "petits enfants rouges" dispersed rapidly among the nobles, crying out "Priuli! Priuli!" at the top of their lungs, a rather un-secret endorsement, I thought.

Each boy carried a small wooden box, a *bussola*, divided into two compartments: one white for "yes," the other green for "no." The common opening was funnel-shaped, cunningly designed to obscure the voter’s hand as he cast his ballot. From a small pouch, a *gibecière*, hanging from their belts, they offered each noble a small ball, no larger than a shirt button. The nobles, in turn, took their ball and, with varying degrees of discretion, dropped it into the compartment of their choice. The process was surprisingly swift. Once the votes were cast for Priuli, the boys gathered their boxes and carried them to the Chancellor, who, with an air of practiced efficiency, emptied the white balls into a large silver basin, discarding the green ones. This procedure was then repeated for each of the other three candidates: Badoar, Donato, and Vendramini.

Finally, the counting of the suffrages began, a swift, almost perfunctory affair after such an elaborate build-up. In what felt like mere moments, the Chancellor announced the outcome: Donato was elected. The speed of it all was truly astonishing, far quicker than I can even recount it to you. We were then ushered out, amidst a fresh wave of noise and movement. What followed, as Donato emerged, was a scene of pure comedy. Nobles rushed forward, performing exaggerated bows and embraces, "prosternations" and "baisers de nourrice" that, I swear, resonated so loudly they could be heard across the entire Piazza. It was a theatrical flourish, a public display of congratulation and feigned camaraderie, typical of this city where every aspect of life, even governance, seems to be played out on a grand stage. It perfectly encapsulated the Venetian spirit: a blend of profound ritual, underlying intrigue, and an undeniable flair for the dramatic.
